INTERVENTION.PARA: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Martina Dlabajová, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the policy program for 2030 "Towards the digital decade" ( COM (2021)0574 – C9-0359/2021 – 2021/0293(COD) ) ( A9-0159/2022 ).
rapporteur . – Mr Commissioner, I am speaking in Czech.

– Madam President, Cloud Services, big data , artificial intelligence, online public services, digital identification, access to medical documents from anywhere or commonly used electronic invoices, this is not science fiction, it must very soon be the reality of all of us. Europe has a chance today to successfully embark on a path that will lead us to a full digital transformation of our economy and society by the end of the decade. Until the time when citizens and companies will fully enjoy the benefits offered by digitization and brought about by the use of new modern technologies.

The political program "Road to the Digital Decade" for 2030 does not invent anything new, but deals with what already exists. It is based on the assumption that the states themselves want to constantly work on improvement and want to cooperate with each other and move forward together. The digitization goals envisaged by the Digital Decade have been consulted with the Member States, and I believe that they are also realistic and achievable. I personally made sure that representatives of companies were also involved in the consultations, not only large ones, but also small and medium-sized ones and start-ups. It is often small and medium-sized companies that are pioneers in a certain area, and others adopt new solutions from them or look for inspiration in them. What do I consider to be the greatest success of our negotiations and the resulting compromise? The Digital Decade comes with handy guidance on how best and most effectively to combine investments from the EU budget, including the Recovery and Resilience Instrument, investments from Member States and also from the private sector. Synergies are the alpha and omega of success and added value. Thanks to the Digital Decade political agenda, we can better address differences between Member States in the areas where it is most needed. And last but not least, we are opening up to the possibilities of international cooperation. However, under clearly defined conditions and according to the agreed rules on the playing field, the programs that finance it.

And what can't we do without? First is connectivity. Without ensuring connectivity, which is still not a given across Europe, we can't do anything and we can all go home right now. A secure and sustainable digital infrastructure is absolutely essential. Yesterday, when the European Parliament became the target of a cyber attack, is a clear example of this. Second, we cannot do without digital skills, and not just the basic ones, which at least 80% of the population should have by the end of 2030. Companies and also the state administration, for example, still lack people who can train and pass on their know-how. I also lack motivation for those already on the job market to learn new skills and develop further. I am not even talking about the long-term desperate call of the labor market for specialists in information and communication technologies. Third, we need digitized public administration services. If we really want citizens and companies to see digitization as a benefit and to see opportunities in it, we have to lead by example. Digitization of the state, access to key public services online, electronic healthcare and I could go on - this must not remain on paper and literally in paper form. And finally, the digital transformation of businesses. A topic with which we could fill the agenda of the entire plenary session, and it still wouldn't be enough. Digitization must pave the way for businesses large and small to do better. And it must not in any case disproportionately burden and demotivate them. I believe we can do it. And as I said before, if we approve the digital decade today, we have already taken the first step on the way to it.

member of the commission . – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I would like to warmly thank the rapporteur, Martina Dlabajová, dear Martina, and the whole team of shadow rapporteurs who have worked tirelessly and in an extremely short in order to finalize this proposal in record time. So thanks to this text, as has just been recalled by the rapporteur, we are going to give Europe the means to organize an ambitious digital transformation.

Over the past three years, faced with all the challenges we have had to manage – and we know that we will still have a lot to manage ahead of us – we have been able to see the real possibilities offered by all the digital technologies. for our entire economy, our economies and more generally for society. And we have implemented an economic recovery also, I remind you, strongly based on digital transformation.

The action program for the digital decade is obviously the vision, the cornerstone of this transformation. For the first time, in fact, we are setting concrete, quantitative and measurable objectives at European level. This is very important for us to achieve what we need to achieve by 2030 in the digital field, because there are no digital decades or a resilient Europe without the excellence of our engineers, without better connectivity throughout Europe, without SMEs also having all the necessary infrastructure, without competitive and sustainable processors – and increasingly, we hope, manufactured on the European continent.

We want Europe to be a fully connected continent, equipped with the necessary infrastructures, capable of storing, transmitting and processing very large areas, gigantic volumes of data, and which subsequently allow other technological developments. And that's why we've set very concrete targets for fiber optics, 5G, cloud , quantum, which is also very important, microelectronics, etc.

Companies that master digital technologies are those that best resist the crisis. We see it every day. It is therefore to be more resilient that, by 2030, we want 90% of our SMEs to increase their capacity in terms of digital technologies.

A society formed in the digital age is also necessary so that our companies are propelled by talented women and men. Our objective in this area is to significantly strengthen the digital skills of all of our fellow European citizens and to also have 20 million engineers specialized in digital in Europe by 2030. And I say that this is a very ambitious objective in which women must play their full role. There really is a very great future for them in this area and we must help them achieve it.

We also aim to ensure access to modern, digital and high-quality public services throughout the European Union. Indeed, it is not a question of setting objectives, it is still necessary to give oneself the means to achieve them. And that's the challenge of the structured process, of the governance monitoring that we put in place. It will enable us to move forward together and without delay by involving all the Member States. This is why the action program includes governance that is solid, transparent, but also, at the same time, flexible enough to be able to follow the objectives and adapt. And for that, we will rely on the experience acquired, in particular within the framework of the national plans for recovery and resilience and, of course, in coordination with the European Semester.

In conclusion, I would like to say that the action program also includes a framework for the development and implementation of multi-country projects, that is, large-scale projects aimed at achieving the digital transformation of the Union and the equally important objectives of industrial recovery. As we know, in this field as in many others, no country can now achieve this alone.

This is why we are equipping ourselves with a new tool, the European Digital Infrastructure Consortium, known as EDIC, and this mechanism will facilitate the pooling of Member States' resources, the Union's budget and private investment . It will thus make it possible to deploy and manage pan-European infrastructures in an efficient manner, for example European data spaces or blockchain . And on our side, I would like to repeat it to you here, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission is ready to react very quickly, as soon as this decision is adopted, to support mature consortium projects.

Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education . – Madam President, dear Commissioner! The European Union must not allow itself to be left behind when it comes to digitization. Europe's start into the digital decade is overdue if we want to compete globally. But all the technological advances we make mean nothing if we don't get people ready and take them with us. Digital literacy will be one of the most important skills we should master in the future. I firmly believe that this will be a decisive factor for the job market.

But in order to achieve this with as many people as possible, one principle applies: First teach the teachers . First of all, we need trained staff who can pass on the knowledge, otherwise we cannot succeed in fundamentally digitizing the population. This affects the teaching staff in schools, but also above all in the area of further education. We must not leave anyone behind when it comes to digitization – no matter what age group, no matter what social class. In my opinion, we have to fulfill three points in order to be successful: we have to train teachers, we have to promote lifelong learning and create the necessary digital infrastructure in schools and educational institutions.

Some EU countries are already much more advanced in digitization than others. But as the saying goes in sport: We are only as strong as our weakest member. So let's tackle it together and bring Europe into the digital decade! Let's use the time now to make the necessary investments in people and infrastructure!

rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs . – Madam President, Commissioner Breton, dear colleagues, congratulations to the rapporteur Martina Dlabajová for the great job on this file. I will begin by saying something that I firmly believe: Europe in the future will be digital or it won’t work at all. There are risks since the dawn of time with all new technologies but, harnessed properly, digitalisation can lead to more access and opportunity for those often left behind, not just for companies and tech giants. We can also use inclusive technologies to integrate people with disabilities. AI can avoid previous human biases in recruitment and, with the right digital skills, more people will gain access to new social prospects. But this will not happen by itself. We have to ensure that digitalisation leaves no one behind, nor is it used to create gaps in our legislation or to exploit workers or curtail their rights. Happy workers mean happy companies. So let’s use the Digital Decade to make that happen in Europe.
for the PPE group . – Madam President, the success of the economic level of the entire Union and the standard of living of our citizens depend on the level of digitization.

From my point of view, three areas are important. First, it is the infrastructure level. We need to invest more in digital infrastructure. We have to motivate private investors to invest in digital infrastructure, and our legislative work is also related to this, to motivate as much as possible for better investments, for better Internet accessibility. Therefore, to make the Internet more accessible and affordable for citizens and companies.

Second, it is the legislative level. We have passed many laws in this Parliament and it is good that we are setting global standards for digital legislation. Well, thirdly, it's the skill level. We need to invest more and more in digital skills, also with European money. Small businesses, which employ the most workers, are also an important topic, and their level of digitization will also determine our success.

I believe that the ambitious goals that by 2030 we will have all documents online in contact with public administration, in contact with public institutions, so that all health records are online, are achievable, and I believe that with the level of digitization we will also advance the standard of living of citizens.
on behalf of the S&D Group . – Madam President, the EU is finally taking a tangible commitment towards digitalisation through important trajectories and targets.

The digital decade we’ve negotiated with the Council gives Member States enough flexibility to pursue digitalisation whilst taking into account their different starting points. Yet digitalisation is not an end in itself, but a means to broader societal outcomes. We have committed to achieving reliable, fast and secure connectivity for everywhere in the Union, including in rural and remote areas such as islands. By 2030, 80% of those aged 16 to 74 should have basic digital skills. There are targets for our SMEs and targets when it comes to big data and AI. A fast and steady creation of digital skills is essential if we want to also address cybersecurity concerns. In this regard, it’s very important that we continue working together.

Until then, however, let’s keep in mind the disadvantaged, our elderly who cannot access the internet and let’s maintain offline accessibility of public services whilst we transit. Whilst the new measures will encourage social inclusion, democratisation of digital skills, narrowing the gender gap, our fight towards a just digital market should continue and our strive towards this. And in this regard, we should agree and work towards stronger digital rights, including access to the internet as a fundamental right.
Let’s ensure that the Europe of 2030 will be digitally ready, fully connected, leading ahead whilst leaving no one behind.

on behalf of the Renew Group . – Madam President, Commissioner Breton, Mrs Martina Dlabajová, dear colleagues, whether we like it or not, the whole world is rapidly moving into a digital age. But this accelerated digitization must put the interest of the citizen at its center.

Our success or failure as a society, as a union will depend on several particularly important aspects. We will have to stimulate the digital field, the companies involved in digitization and give the possibility to specialists to develop their ideas here in the European Union. There will be an absolute need for programs and projects that teach citizens to use digital tools, create and live in a digital environment. Last but not least, we must keep in mind that this digitization must make people's work and life easier.

We don't digitize for the sake of digitization, we do it for the benefit of people. All this, however, can only be done if we have a European approach at Union level, to ensure that the rights of all European citizens are respected, that we all have the same chances, no matter what region we live in, that no one is left behind .

on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group . – Madam President, Mr Commissioner, rapporteurs, shadow rapporteurs, colleagues, during this decade, we want to give the EU’s digital transition a decisive boost. We had the Compass and now, with today’s decision, we have the concrete targets that we as a Union need to achieve by 2030 and the way to get there. Now all we need to do is to add political will and financial resources to these tools.

In the digitalisation of the economy and society, much is at stake. We have to avoid lagging behind in terms of competitiveness for our economy and companies. We strive to be able to compete for leadership positions in the field of ICT and other advanced technologies. Issues such as territorial balance, technological sovereignty, the efficiency of public services and administration, energy sustainability or social cohesion are also at stake.

Incorporation into the digital world should not result in more fractures and divides in our societies. This is why it is so important that the targets that we have agreed upon produce positive effects in each and every of these areas.

On the positive balance of the final outcome, I want to emphasise the fact that we included the regional dimension in the digital transition. There are sub-state governments, like the Catalan government, that are very active in digital policies, and it’s good that they become involved with the joint endeavour to reach the 2030 targets.

On the negative side, I regret that governments didn’t accept even the possibility for the Commission to issue recommendations to those Member States not on track with digital benchmarks. That no doubt would have helped the implementation of the targets.

It’s also regrettable that we couldn’t fully counter the big push from some big Member States to introduce in the final text a reference, albeit indirectly, to the so-called fair share principle for investments in digital infrastructures. We need to ensure that net neutrality rules will not be changed and consumers and businesses will not have to pay more for online services due to a misleading concept of fair share. But this is a story to be continued.

on behalf of the group ID . – Madam President, Commissioner, Hon. Dlabajová, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank Mrs Dlabajová for her fruitful cooperation and for also accepting our contributions.

This decision sets out concrete digital goals that the European Union intends to achieve by the end of the decade, as has been said, and we felt that we were going in the right direction. However, we have inserted and highlighted the problem of the reskilling because we need to find funding to digitize people over 50 who are not familiar with these new tools and who have to update themselves to face new needs. These generations possess extensive know-how, a wealth of information and content and can support the new recruits with experience, who will have digital IT skills.

The intergenerational meeting must be inclusive so that everyone benefits and also to achieve the goal of having the 20 million specialists employed in the information and communication technologies sector. Thus the European Union must resort to the use of all programmes, especially research, such as for example creating a stronger link with the EIT and with KIC Digital.

The attention paid to small and medium-sized enterprises is good, we must devote all our attention to them to prevent our economic and social fabric from deteriorating. Our companies must be supported in the transition process with targeted courses and funding and European politics must take care of this.

Then we liked that the Commission will develop together with the Member States trajectories at European level for each of the digital objectives of the European Union and, in turn, the Member States will have to commit themselves to develop the national strategic trajectories and roadmaps to achieve these objectives, which must be clear and sustainable.

Furthermore, the concept of multinational projects will facilitate investment in areas such as high-performance computing, common data infrastructure and services, blockchain, high-tech partnership for digital skills and secure quantum infrastructure, as well as the network of security, digital public administration, testing facilities and digital innovation clusters.

Many Italian companies and industries are interested in these infrastructure projects and we hope that our favorable vote will serve as a driving force for the achievement of the established objectives.

for the ECR group . - Madam Speaker! The EU has become the world champion at regulating digitization, instead of supporting innovation and new thinking. We have therefore fallen behind on a global level. I support the idea of investing in digital development, because it is something good, but I fear that this strategy will fail. I hope I'm wrong. It contains many beautiful words and incredibly ambitious goals, instead of an effective strategy that will give value for our money. It is through economic reforms and education that we create sustainable development for the future and not through inefficient bureaucracy that gives rise to waste.

Although the EU spends more money than both the US and Asia on digitalisation, we are still lagging behind. This is not reasonable. We cannot continue in the same rut, but we must start thinking anew.

on behalf of The Left Group . – Madam President, digital technologies have the potential to improve citizens' access to information and culture, as well as to provide them with a wider, more diversified and easier choice in accessing public goods and services and to enhance their quality of life.

But this guide for the digital decade follows the neoliberal blueprint of the European institutions, oriented towards the single digital market, which has been an instrument that promotes inequalities between Member States, making life particularly difficult for micro, small and medium-sized companies, which they cannot cope with competition and the brutal inequality of means and resources that are within reach of the large multinational companies in the sector, and now also of the already institutionalized unicorns.

According to the proposal, the Member States should draw up national roadmaps subject to specific recommendations per country, formulated within the framework of the European Semester, which we are opposed to as an integral part of the European Union's imposition, conditioning and control instruments on policies of the Member States.
Reality shows that the script should already be different.

– Madam President, dear Commissioner, dear Colleagues, dear Rapporteur Martina Dlabajová, the digital transition is one of the pillars of the European Union's strategy for the next decade. The competitiveness of our economy will largely depend on its success. This is a race we are starting late in, compared to some countries, such as the United States.

In order to recover ground, we must invest heavily in infrastructure, in the modernization of companies, industries and public services, in the data economy, in a strong digital internal market, in education and training, both for staff and for the general population, in scientific research and innovation .

The affirmation of the European Union will involve a commitment to emerging technologies such as quantum computing. We must be able to create the conditions for these technologies to develop and be produced in Europe.

A good example of the way forward are the Horizon Europe Partnerships covering topics such as essential digital technologies and integrated circuits, high-performance computing and 5G and 6G networks.
This roadmap for the digital decade, with its ambitious objectives, will only be achieved if all these conditions are met.

– Madam President, Commissioner, digitization opens up many opportunities for Europeans, also for their territories, but it can also generate exclusions and increase inequalities that we undoubtedly have to combat through public policies and also with greater democratic participation. This itinerary for the digital decade 2030 has the objective of strengthening European digital sovereignty, which is undoubtedly an essential element to guarantee our resilience and also our strategic autonomy.

I am especially pleased to see included in the final agreement the need to guarantee basic digital skills and an increase in these objectives for 80% of people, and thus allow citizens to have the basic skills necessary to fully participate in the digital society and finally achieve broad digital literacy.

I am especially pleased, and it has been a great effort by our group, the socialists and democrats, that there are specific support measures to overcome the serious gender imbalance, since only one in six specialists in information and communication technology , and only one in three graduates in STEM, that is, in science, technology, engineering and mathematics, are women.
And, finally, also the regional variable, since no region can be left behind in this digital progress.

– Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, today, for the first time, we are setting clear milestones to collectively make our European digital ambition a reality. This ambition is that of a digital world built around people, which respects fundamental rights. An innovative world, accessible to all. A world that relies on skills strengthened throughout Europe.
Ladies and gentlemen, if we want to make this digital revolution a success, we will have to meet two imperatives.

First imperative: the digitization of our societies must go hand in hand with our climate commitments. We need sustainable infrastructure and greener digital. But we also need to develop digital technologies that will enable us to reduce our emissions in agriculture, energy and transport.

Second imperative: we will need – we know – substantial investments if we want to achieve our objectives for 2030. This effort should be carried out fairly between the main digital players concerned. This is an important point. The European Declaration on Digital Rights and Principles for the Digital Decade makes this clear. We will have the opportunity to discuss it very extensively.

– Madam President, thank you to the rapporteur, thank you, Commissioner, for being here with us. There is a blind spot in this text: for me, it is the sustainable question and it is the green question. The digital decade takes us to 2030. We have climate objectives by 2030. And in this text, there is nothing that frames what we decide to implement as infrastructure in order to be able to meet these objectives.

When we talk about digital development, there is a question that we do not ask. However, when we want to define social criteria and environmental criteria, we do impact studies. Here, for digital, impact studies are optional.

The digital issue is a question of infrastructure. These infrastructures lead to uses. Any coherent strategy for an economic power like ours should be conditioned by the question of knowing what the real needs are. It is decreed in this text that 90% of SMEs should be digital intensive. For what? Where do these numbers come from? Why don't we have a more sober, more resilient analysis of digital design?

I mean that in the world in which we find ourselves, the European Union must be a political power for strategy and stabilization. Today, there are two dominant digital models in the world: that of China – obviously we don't want to look like them – and that of the American GAFAMs – and I don't think we should look like them either. What is the European alter-model in this area? From the beginning, we have been told that digital is a natural ally of the ecological transition. All the studies, all the studies that exist on the ecological impact of digital technology show precisely the opposite. I would like us to be lucid in this area. Not all technology is good, necessarily, in itself. It is the political power that decides to ensure that a technological innovation is at the service of the common good. I hope that in the weeks, months and years to come, our institution will ensure that this is the case for digital.
– (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the pandemic has highlighted the need for greater digitization of our economy and society.

In fact, the digital transformation offers us a great opportunity to create new opportunities for young Europeans and improve accessibility to digital skills and make them more usable for all citizens. Increasing the digital skills of European citizens, who are in a situation of substantial lag compared to other industrialized countries, is of fundamental importance.

This passes through the enhancement of the digital infrastructure, which must be brought to the highest standards to ensure competitiveness and security. With this in mind, European production of cutting-edge and sustainable semiconductors should represent at least 20% of the value of world production by 2030. In fact, European industry is discounting the shortage of microchips and semiconductors due to the post COVID-19 financial crisis and only an increase in indigenous production will allow our continent to keep pace with competitor such as the United States, India and China.

The final aspect to consider is the digitization of public services, with the aim of making online public services fully accessible to all citizens by 2030. Everyone in the European Union should benefit from a quality digital environment, which offers user-friendly, efficient and personalized services and tools, with high standards in terms of security and protection of privacy. Only by ensuring that all key public services are available online for businesses and citizens will Europe be able to strengthen its digital leadership and meet the challenges that globalization has imposed on it.

– Madam President! Mr. Commissioner! The fourth industrial revolution, artificial intelligence, the COVID-19 pandemic have shown that the transformation of our economy and society towards a more digital one is our urgent goal. We urgently need to accelerate the process of educating and developing digital infrastructure in all European Union countries. That is why this joint program "Road towards the Digital Decade" is so important.
I am very happy that young people are listening to this important debate today, because for them it is the future of the whole of Europe. For you are the most in this digital economy.

The European Union must be ambitious, modern and digital, because it will guarantee a profit for Europe of almost EUR 3 trillion. For example, for my country, Poland, it is nearly PLN 500 billion. Today, unfortunately, most Europeans have only basic digital competences, and huge differences persist between countries. The proportion of Europeans with basic digital skills varies between 29% and 79%.

Today, this compromise worked out by our Parliament and the European Council requires an ambitious approach and cooperation. We have set specific objectives for digital policy, digital skills, infrastructure and digitization of enterprises, and most importantly, a transparent framework for the implementation of multinational projects. However, in this ambitious project, we should pay attention to several sensitive issues: regarding the timing of the publication of national digital roadmaps and the achievement of the targets of 70% for EU companies using digitization in doing business and 100% digital transformation in access to public services and access by citizens, e.g. for medical records. However, let us remember that in this rush to the world's digital civilization, it is important not to forget about other people, about our safety, and to pay attention to the threats posed by technological progress and the digital world.
– Madam President, Commissioner Breton, ladies and gentlemen! We are talking today about the road to a digital decade and I would like to pick out three points, following what Mrs Carvalho said.

First of all, I believe that it is very important for the European Union to pursue a value-based digital policy. And that is why this statement on digital rights and principles that you, dear Commissioner Breton, and the Commission have presented is fundamental. Digital policy in Europe must meet the same standards as the very traditional economic and social policy that we pursue. There can be no different digital politics.

That's why I believe that we have – secondly – achieved a lot in the past few months: the law on digital markets, the law on digital services, the Data Act – and we are still waiting for the specification of the Data Acts with regard to automobiles – are important steps. But we need integration into the respective departments for all these steps, and we do not need a separate digital super-auditing authority, as is currently envisaged in the law on artificial intelligence. Digital politics must take place wherever politics already takes place today, and there must always be a balance between analog services and digital services.

Therefore, lastly, thirdly, dear Commissioner Breton: I think we must also discuss the spectrum policy think again - because if we really want to achieve a digital single market, if we want to become more competitive in telecommunications services, then we need a cross-border market and for that telecommunications providers need more opportunities. That's why your courage is required. I would like to encourage you to do this; Parliament stands by your side.
– Madam President, Commissioner, let us be clear.

At a time when we are strongly committed to a Digital Identity at the service of all European citizens, as the basis for having a more inclusive and democratic digital television, there is another digital identity that counts: the Digital Identity of our partnership, the European Union. Anchored in the common values that we share for the journey to 2030, examples of which are: the defense of a digital society focused on people, inclusive, safe and transparent, and the tendentially universal access of all European citizens to high quality networks, through technology, economic resources, skills development, allowing them to take advantage of available services and, in particular, services of public interest in digital format.

It is the affirmation of this differentiated digital identity that can allow us not only to fulfill our objectives as a partnership for peace, freedom and democracy, but also to be relevant and competitive on a global scale.

That's why we have to combine all technologies, including the new generations of WI-FI, following the spirit of the initiative Wifi4EU , for which I was rapporteur, and also to open a broad front for financing the modernization of the networks, including the platforms that depend on them.
– (IT) Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the digital transformation of our society and our economy is one of the great challenges facing the European Union.

The Commission did well in setting specific targets to be achieved between now and 2030, which will allow us to play a global role. As happened with the Green Deal, in fact, only if we have measurable and tangible goals will we be able to monitor our progress in this field.

I would like to underline two elements of this strategy that I consider particularly significant. The first: the need to invest to ensure the maximum diffusion of digital skills and an adequate number of highly qualified digital professionals, especially among young people, to be competitive on the labor market as well.
The second element is the need to invest in the digitization of companies, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, to make the most of the opportunities that technology offers them.
All of this will certainly also depend on the ability to ensure secure and resilient connectivity and digital infrastructures that reach everyone.

– Honorable Chairperson, ladies and gentlemen, have you been tested? Have you tried to see how many minutes you can last and listen to a speaker in an official meeting or even a private meeting without reaching for your smartphone in case you don't see something very important that just arrived.

So we all lose focus. We are all looking for an attraction. We have all become addicted in some way. And that's why, when we talk about digitization, especially about the education of young people, we should also think about human weaknesses so that technologies can really be at the service of people.

Also, we should know exactly how much this digitization will reduce administration, how much our citizens and entrepreneurs will really pay less for administration, and how much simpler, faster and easier these processes will be. So that it doesn't happen like in Croatia, where we had several digital transformations, but for most public services they always ask you for just one more piece of paper.

– Madam President, I would say that COVID has really demonstrated the value of digitalisation and technologies, how important they are to our societies. We’ve seen the benefits of bringing people together, delivering services, allowing business to continue, and indeed delivering particularly our education services. But we can’t stop there. We need to do more. And I very much welcome the programme, the ‘Path to the Digital Decade’, and also the Digital Scoreboard, because I think it’s good to shine a light on individual countries and set targets and how we can improve our societies, our economies.

By 2030, we want at least 80% of adults to have basic digital skills, and we must leave nobody behind. That means age, education and social background should not be a deterrent. We need to ensure that all households have gigabyte connectivity and all population areas should be covered by 5G. That’s really important. We also need to ensure that our government and our state services are delivered digitally so that we don’t leave anybody behind in this area, particularly those who are living in rural isolated areas.
So the targets are there and it’s a challenge. But absolutely, as I started, COVID has demonstrated just how important this is for all our societies.

– Madam President, dear Commissioner Breton, dear rapporteur, colleagues, strengthening the strategic digital capacity and deployment of advanced technologies will support our businesses, benefit our citizens and definitely ensure Europe’s digital autonomy. Proper implementation of Europe’s digital decade policy programme will provide citizens with better jobs, better healthcare and better public services. Digital progress is crucial if we want to achieve our climate neutral, fair and green social goals.

However, we still have to guarantee four important things. First, better digital infrastructure and connectivity across Europe. Second, enhance partnership between Member States. Third, better digital skills. And fourth, effective public services across all the Member States. All these objectives are crucial if we want to achieve our goals for 2030 digital targets.
Europe has the capacity to be a global digital leader where technological advancement, fair and green economic growth, social inclusion and business competitiveness are all equally respected.

– Honorable Chairperson, ladies and gentlemen, the digital transformation of our society and economy? That. Digitization? Absolutely yes. But we must not forget the influence of technology on man. Man must always be at the center of all programs, and the constant education of people is a priority in the years ahead.

Unfortunately, we are aware that excessive use of digital devices and digital addiction are part of our everyday life, especially among young people. That's why, respected Commissioner Breton, I call on the Commission to strengthen and financially help and strengthen education programs, especially for young people, so that they can use the opportunities that are in front of us in a correct and healthy way, and we should never skimp on that.
Digitization and digital transformation, namely, will be successful and meaningful only if this digitalization, this technology, is used by healthy and happy people, both at work and at home.
– Madam President! It is hard not to support the goal of advancing digitization to increase innovation, efficiency of the economy or streamlining administration.

However, the civilizational breakthrough that the world is currently experiencing as a result of the fourth industrial revolution brings new challenges and controversies related to the use of digital technologies and artificial intelligence. By creating huge development opportunities, it also created various threats, including the risk of digital abuse, violation of privacy, surveillance, dehumanization and alienation of people. There are numerous cases in which erroneous decisions of computer algorithms and artificial intelligence result in violation of the rights and freedoms of many citizens.

The "Road to the Digital Decade" program does not provide a sufficient response to public concerns about the potential negative effects of the implementation of digital technologies. However, we find here a provision that is characteristic of today's EU documents that these technologies are to be consistent with EU values.

But what are these "Union values"? Are these values historically co-creating the European spirit, such as Christian ethics? Or are they rather an expression of leftist ideological aspirations, which, instead of the benefits of new technologies, will bring us the totalitarianism of a brave new world?

– Madam President! Mr. Commissioner! Ladies and Gentlemen! In recent years, the words "digital transformation" have been inflected on all occasions. The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly accelerated the ongoing processes and forced us to adapt to the new reality through the more widespread use of digital technologies. However, there is no doubt that for the European Union to be able to truly successfully and fully implement the digital transformation, we need a coherent strategy. The 2030 Road to the Digital Decade policy agenda is the right step in this direction.

The program has great potential. It outlines ambitious digital targets for the entire Union in terms of priority areas. They will be achieved through individual national paths. Of course, it is impossible to mention all the objectives in a minute, but the most important ones are definitely: enabling citizens to access public services 100% online, significantly increasing the number of digital specialists, increasing digital skills and combating exclusion, as well as digitizing enterprises. I believe that thanks to this strategy, we will be able to achieve the indicated objectives more efficiently at Union level.

- President, Commissioner, the digital transformation of European economies and societies is moving at a very fast pace, and this is bringing with it a number of new opportunities but at the same time critical challenges that we must address in the future.

Recent crises, without a doubt, highlight the key role of digital transformation in building a sustainable future for European citizens. At the same time, these crises exposed, in a very strong way, the digital divide that exists between citizens, and the need to adopt digital solutions that are accessible to different regions, countries and sectors. And that's why we need additional commitments to guarantee a fair transition, an inclusive transition that doesn't leave anyone behind; with concrete goals, public investment and interventions in strategic sectors to ensure ecological and digital progress for all, including providing protections and opportunities even to the most remote communities, to the most peripheral communities.

Therefore, I support the contribution that initiatives such as the Digital Decade can have in achieving a cohesive digital transformation for European society by 2030, in particular to overcome the gap between rural and urban areas.
– Madam President, it is undoubtedly good that we are setting goals for digitalisation. Unfortunately, we don't have a very good selection of them.

They do not measure the results for the citizen. For example, the goal of making key public services available online. After all, it is not enough that the service is available online, because the online service can be made in such a way that citizens lose more time with it than if they visited the office on foot. If you don't believe it, read about how the online service for registering for vaccination against Covid worked in Slovakia, in my member state.

Instead, targets such as how much time savings have increased, costs have decreased, or how much labor productivity has increased due to digitization would be more appropriate. Such goals are mostly missing from the draft, and I think it's a shame. I am convinced of that.

– Madam President, dear Commissioner, dear colleagues! Today we are discussing our political program for the digital strategy in order, as the saying goes, to get fit for the location of the future. It's about infrastructure, artificial intelligence, 5G, 6G, cloud computing, blockchain and much more.

It's also about quantum computing, and I want to touch on that briefly. The report – by the way, congratulations, rapporteur – underlines that quantum computing capabilities are becoming a crucial requirement. We want to have our first quantum computer by 2025, so that by 2030 we can achieve an absolute top position in the field of quantum capacities. And I think we, as the European Union, have great potential to really become global pioneers in this area.

It is with a little pride, Commissioner, that I can say that the world's first quantum architecture company is located in my home region - in Tyrol. We have to create the framework conditions for such companies – this is how a European ecosystem for quantum computing can change the world.

– Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, without a doubt, one of the political priorities of this European Commission, of this European Parliament is the Digital Decade. A Digital Decade that not only serves as an engine of transformation, but this Roadmap towards the Digital Decade for 2030 puts on the horizon real problems that we have today in the European Union.
And I want to focus mainly on three of them, which we must be able to address in a coordinated way and, above all, looking for results by 2030. They are related to reducing the digital divide.
Men currently hold eight out of ten jobs in the telecommunications sector in the European Union. Therefore, women continue to be left out of those jobs related to digitization.
But it is not only a problem for women, but also for SMEs. In the European Union we have a low participation of SMEs in digitization and we must, as the European Union, bet on them.
But, above all, I also want to focus on a transcendental element: the rural world. We cannot continue creating two Europes, at two speeds; that of the rural world and that of the big cities.

Therefore, this digital itinerary has a clear objective: to reduce gaps. And our task as the European Parliament, without a doubt, is to make it as effective as possible and, above all, to make it a reality in the year 2030.
– (IT) Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, with the ever-increasing importance and use of digital, it is increasingly difficult for citizens and businesses to keep up.

New technologies contribute to economic and social development, but are accompanied by risks, insecurity and disinformation. Many small and medium-sized businesses have been left on their own during the transition to IT management.

Dedicating a greater percentage of the device's budget for recovery and resilience to the digital transition is essential to give all companies the opportunity to be part of a virtual network that connects and unites all member countries.

Furthermore, data security is often underestimated. Informing and providing directives on the subject is essential for the success of this vision. Connecting member countries can and should serve to increase financial opportunities through guidelines and protocols that facilitate data exchange.
Europe will have to show itself united in setting precise objectives and indicating the right paths to facilitate this unstoppable progress.

– Madam President! Sir. Commissioner! A pleasure! Digitization takes up more and more space in our society, in our everyday life and in our economy. But even though digitization has already changed a lot in our lives, we must dare to go even further. Digitization ensures both jobs, growth and prosperity. That is why I am happy about the ambitious goals in the programme. If the EU is to be at the forefront of the digital transition, and I think the EU must, then we need more digital experts, internet for all, and more companies and public services using digital solutions. I myself come from one of the world's most digitized countries, and therefore I also know the reverse side of the coin. There are some who lose their jobs when they become automated, and there are some who lack the digital skills to be able to join. Therefore, it is also important that we ensure that no one is left behind on the platform. No one should be left behind in digitalisation, and therefore we must make a special effort to ensure this. We must ensure that those who lose their jobs are retrained, and we must ensure that we give people the skills they need to participate in digitalisation. Maybe even offer that you can access public services without having these skills. We must therefore be more digital, while at the same time protecting those who find it difficult to participate. That is the prerequisite for us to succeed in the EU.

– Madam President, dear colleagues, Commissioner, as the energy and economic crisis continue to loom large, there is a growing risk that many European citizens and companies will fall behind and not reap the benefits of the digital transformation. To accelerate the pace of digital innovation and adoption, it is crucial that we match the 2030 target with a set of investments that will help close the digital divide and keep our ambitions high.

First, we need to invest in people and education so that our citizens have the digital skills necessary to actively participate in the digital society. The digital decade must be inclusive and make digital technology work for people and for businesses. Second, the quality, access and transparency of public services through digitalisation should be improved and modernised across the EU.
The point is not to win the digital race. The point is to develop and safeguard our societies.

– Madam President, Commissioner, I am glad that we are debating this topic and this issue, digitization. Of course, we know that the proverb exists in all situations: "the road to hell is paved with good intentions".

It's very important, and I'm glad you spoke, Commissioner, that it's not enough just to invest in technology, we also need to increase skills, because now, as we speak, there are whole geographical areas, especially in rural areas, where we don't we don't even have infrastructure, there is no signal for the phone, what digitization are we talking about? And the skills must be increased simultaneously with the investments, because otherwise it would be a loss if we invest in digitization, but we don't have the skills to access it.

I also believe in the positive effects of digitization, in good effects to integrate people with disabilities, but to the same extent I believe very much that investments should be targeted to geographical areas, to areas where we still have problems related to skills and infrastructure.
That's why I believe that digitization goes hand in hand with investment and goes hand in hand with education and increasing the digital skills of all citizens in the internal market space.

member of the commission . – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you sincerely for the very enriching debate we have had today. We are obviously all aware that we must act urgently, with determination, to build the digital decade.

You have already supported us in a large number of essential files for our digital space, our informational space, on the scale of our continent. Many others are under discussion, as you know. It is therefore essential for us, political decision-makers, to do everything possible to ensure that the current transformation meets the needs and expectations of all our citizens, I mean all our citizens and, of course, of our companies, whether they are big or small. It is time to overcome the inequalities between those who benefit from this transformation and the others, as many of you have been reminded of.

Affirming our identity and a European model that reflects our values in a digital world is effectively becoming an essential issue for us, but also on the scale of the continent and the planet. This is why the action program for the digital decade is so important. This is our roadmap for leading the digital transition with our citizens, governments and businesses. It is also crucial to reduce our technological dependencies and avoid creating new ones in a world that will become increasingly complex, as we know.

The novelty of this action program is above all that it sets – you and yourselves rightly reminded you, Madam Rapporteur – of the quantitative objectives to be achieved and, in doing so, commit the Member States to a new form of governance.
I would like to recall here, in conclusion, ladies and gentlemen, that the Commission will obviously play its full role in implementing this program as soon as possible.

reporter . – Madam President, Commissioners, colleagues, thank you for all the constructive comments, opinions and your support. The road to the digital decade will not be easy. It will zigzag in places, there will often be an obstacle that we will have to jump or climb over. Still, I'm glad we went for it. I thank the European Commission, I thank the member states that we have found a common vision of what this path should look like. The French presidency, which laid the foundations, and the Czech presidency, which followed up and successfully concluded the negotiations, deserve thanks. Thanks also to all the shadow reporters and all our teams. I would like it to be said once again that we were able to agree together with the Commission and the Council on what needs to be monitored in order to know whether the goals of the digital decade are being met or not. Sufficient information and learning from past mistakes are fundamental building blocks for progress, and I already look forward to the annual State of the Digital Decade report.

The Digital Decade is a political program with specific goals and is set up to guide countries and show the direction of how to successfully meet these goals. It is a common strategy and it is in everyone's interest to follow it. I believe that with your help I have managed to find the right mix to achieve full digitization by 2030. Let's not forget that we are talking here all the time about 20 million experts in the field of ICT, about digital skills for more than 360 million Europeans, about securing millions of high-speed internet connections across the EU, the creation of 10,000 climate-neutral, highly secure edge nodes, the first quantum-accelerated computer, the use of cloud services, artificial intelligence, big data processing by three-quarters of EU businesses or full digitization public administration and healthcare. And all this in just eight years.

Maybe it still seems like science-fiction or a fairy tale, but I believe that in 2030 it will turn out that we did everything right. Now it's up to you and your vote. Thank you for your attention and I look forward to seeing how today's vote turns out.
The debate is closed.
The vote will take place today, Thursday 24 November 2022.

in writing . – The 'Digital Decade' programme, if successfully implemented, could, according to existing calculations, contribute to an additional EUR 2.8 trillion across the Union. If the implementation of digital technologies in Poland is accelerated and the assumptions of the EU plan are implemented, it is possible to obtain an additional PLN 491 billion in GDP by 2030. While most Europeans have basic digital competences, significant differences remain between countries, with the proportion of the population having at least basic digital skills ranging from 29% to 79%. In order to achieve the goal set in the program, according to which by 2030, 80% of the population should have basic digital skills, it is necessary to accelerate the process of education and development of digital infrastructure. If the overall take-up of basic digital skills has increased by only 4-5% over the past five years, this calls into question goals such as increasing the number of cloud-intensive businesses and digitizing public services. I am satisfied with the compromise reached by the EP and the EU Council. In particular, the importance of the mechanism for managing their implementation and monitoring the results should be emphasized, which has been planned so as not to generate burdens for public administrations of the PM. I see some shortcomings in the insufficiently synchronized timing of the publication of national digital road maps and in too little time for the development of national digital road maps.
