INTERVENTION.PARA: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on the European Year of Youth 2022 - Legacy ( 2022/2953(RSP) ).

member of the commission . – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, on behalf of my colleague Mariya Gabriel, I would like here to share with you the final preliminary observations of the Commission concerning the assessment that we draw from the Year of Youth 2022.

This European Year of Youth had a clear objective: to put young people at the centre, to listen to what they have to say to us and to act accordingly, by strengthening their skills so that they can develop their ideas and above all by preparing them to participate to political debates. This has enabled more young people to mobilize, to get involved also at the political level, to engage and to raise awareness among their peers of the opportunities offered by the European Union. According to the organizers of the various activities, more than 150 million European citizens have been made aware. These opportunities have opened up new channels for young people to make their views heard, to engage in policy-making at different levels and therefore to influence their content.

But beyond this aspect, it is now time to discuss and reflect on what worked well and what can be further developed. The Commission has thus begun a process of reviewing the results obtained and our debate today contributes to this process. Feedback will be welcomed from national coordinators of the European Year of Youth, youth actors themselves and young people, and will form part of the report on the implementation of the Year which will then be communicated to the co-legislators before the end of 2023. All of these reflections will also feed into the mid-term evaluation by the end of 2023 of the Union's youth strategy for the period 2019-2027, our plan long-term common aim, I remind you, of mobilizing young people and connecting them by giving them the means to act.

Without waiting, we have already seen that the European Year of Youth has brought about a number of major achievements. First, on October 28 and 29, the corridors of the European Parliament in Brussels echoed with the voices of over 1,300 young activists who took part in the “LevelUp! Youth Boot Camp”. These young people developed their skills through workshops and networking events. The event itself resonated, if I may say so, on social media, with nearly 40,000 young people from across Europe coming forward and communicating together. This is the ripple effect we wanted to create.

In addition, more than 8,000 other activities can be listed on the European Youth Portal. While the majority of these activities took place face-to-face or in a hybrid format, the mobilization of social networks and online campaigns made it possible to reach millions of young people all over the Union.

The year saw new partnerships and new connections, including within the Commission. An example is the new social automation initiative, known as ALMA – guidance, learning, mastery, success – under the European Social Fund Plus. It aims to help disadvantaged young people to integrate into the labor market and into the society of their country of origin, following, for example, work or other experience in another Member State.

We also continued to strengthen existing initiatives with the hugely popular European Coding Week to ensure equal access to digital skills for all children, regardless of economic background or money.

Two important initiatives in the field of research and innovation also deserve to be highlighted. As part of the European Cities of Science programme, Leiden hosted the 33rd edition of the European Competition for Young Scientists, bringing together 132 young, very bright minds, selected from more than 65,000 participants from all over the world. We have also launched a new European research infrastructure called “Growing Up in Digital Europe – EuroCohort”, which will be a unique source of high-quality and reliable statistical data to support the development of social policies and improve the well-being of children, young people and their families across Europe.

The Commission has also launched new initiatives that give young people opportunities and spaces to express themselves, to make their visions and ideas heard, to influence and inspire their peers and society at large. These include the Youth Voices platform, the pool of young European journalists, political dialogues with Commissioners and the various networks of youth ambassadors.

Finally, new partnerships and new links have been established between the institutions of the European Union, the Member States and youth organisations. Within the European Commission, we are currently reflecting on how to continue the cooperation with the group of national coordinators of the European Year of Youth as well as with the national contact points and stakeholders. In addition to the representatives appointed by the Member States, more than 120 youth actors were part of this group. Representatives of the European Parliament, the Committee of the Regions, the European Economic and Social Committee were also part of this network. And I want to tell you here that this collaboration has been extremely valuable.

on behalf of the PPE Group . – Madam President, dear Commissioner! The European Year of Youth was the right initiative at the right time, because young people showed particular solidarity during the Corona pandemic. It was therefore only fitting that we made them our priority in 2022.

But I think we could have done even better if we had communicated more deeply to the bottom, to the bottom. A lot of young people didn't even know that we had a European Year of Youth. This is in urgent need of improvement. We should have involved them even more from the start, also at the grassroots level and not just at the grassroots level Brussels bubble .

We learned a lot from the exchanges with young people this year: what moves them, what they want from politics. But what matters most now is what we make of it. The year must not be a flash in the pan that ends on December 31st. It must have a long-term legacy because we need real political participation from young people and we owe them tangible outputs.

We promised ourselves here last year that the European Year of Youth would not just be a nice to have should be, and now is our chance to prove we mean business. Let's take up the young people's input and create structures for better participation!

Topics such as participation of young people and better participation - for example a youth test, a structural dialogue with young people –, issues such as sustainable climate and environmental policy, the issue of mental health, the issue of jobs and skills – and thanks to the Commission for next year being the European Year of Skills; this also picks up on an aspect that the young people brought forward - and the topic of digitization: it was them big five , which we must continue to pursue in the future; these were the topics that were brought into focus again and again at the EYE event, but also at many, many other youth events.

Let us continue to work on this together with the younger generation in the coming years and not over the heads of the young people – in my opinion that would be the most important output of this year, that we act together with the young people.

for the S&D group . - Madam President! Commissioner! We have war in Europe, we have a climate crisis and we still have the consequences of the pandemic plaguing us. Young people all over Europe experience all this and are very worried about it. In my country, Sweden, the young generation answers that hope is diminishing. Fewer than half today see their future brightly. That is why it is so important that we take the concerns of children and young people seriously, and that is why a European Year of Youth was welcome.

The EU has so much to offer young people: high-class student exchanges within Erasmus, the opportunity to travel by train and discover Europe, a first job or an internship in another EU country, perhaps here in the parliament. However, we can do even more. We need more student exchanges, smoother train routes and decent wages and conditions.

The European Year of Youth must be more than individual events and seminars. It must be a kick-start for a policy for young people that shows continued solidarity with Ukraine, that is equal and inclusive and that really takes the climate crisis seriously. There is a lot at stake in our EU. Let the European Year of Youth be a turning point of hope for all young people in the EU, for the future of our Union.

on behalf of Renew Group . – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, yes, it was a good idea to make 2022 the European Year of Youth. I defended this idea when it was presented by President von der Leyen. We were in the midst of COVID. Young people had suffered heavily from confinement in their daily lives. It changed their daily life. Yes, it was a good idea, but we can't stop there.

So yes, there has been progress. The involvement of young people has progressed, but we have not achieved anything concrete. And that is the worst thing in politics: broken promises, those that make abstainers, that make citizens turn away from us. For example, we asked to respect the commitments on the conference on the future of Europe by consulting young people on the major policies that concern them and that affect them. We were expecting this announcement during Ursula von der Leyen's State of the Union address, but it didn't come.
We asked to engage a European framework for quality and fairly remunerated internships. We also called for a youth mental health framework. Nothing concrete has been announced.

So, I am particularly proud, with my Renew group, my colleagues, Dragoş Pîslaru, to have set up a working group that puts young people at the heart of political consultation and our reflections. We move forward together.

But, at the level of the European Union, the work remains to be completed. This is why the European Year of Youth must continue for another six months and this is what we are calling for in this resolution.

on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group . – Madam President, Commissioner, this European Year of Youth has put our institutions in the mirror and, unfortunately, not everything that the reflection returns to us pleases us.
Young people continue to face precariousness and an almost always difficult transition to working life.

The impacts of the pandemic, the recent war in Ukraine, the rising cost of living, energy poverty and a climate emergency that makes it difficult to imagine a future, have only contributed to worsening the already critical mental health situation of our girls. and adolescents.

Being a young woman, being a young person from the LGTBIQ+ community, being a young migrant, a young person, a refugee, a young person with a disability or several of these things at the same time, entails great challenges, such as having fewer opportunities.

But, as a summary, I would tell you that this year leaves us with good news, a lesson and several challenges. The good news is, for example, this debate, which allows us to name problems that have often been relegated to the margins and put young people at the center of the agenda.
The lesson: a European year that is not prepared in advance can hardly set solid objectives and achieve ambitious goals.

And the challenges: we have to materialize what we in Parliament have strongly called for, that is, a common framework to guarantee fair remuneration for traineeships, accessibility to stigma-free mental health care and, ultimately, but perhaps the most important challenge is to involve and listen to young people in the preparation of all European policies and also in the evaluation of their impact.

In short, we have to promote structural changes to build a more inclusive European political system with young people based on anti-racism, free of discrimination and gender violence. We need mechanisms and policies that positively reflect the position and role that young people play as active members of society.
During the European Year of Youth we have demanded that the voices of young people be put at the center and now we demand that these voices remain.

on behalf of group ID . – Madam President, Commissioner, your conception of the youth of our various nations is completely misguided. This motion for a resolution on the European Year of Youth is therefore an opportunity to recall a few points.

You only speak to the youth of the metropolises, the one you represent, wearing the veil, while the Iranian youth are desperately trying to get rid of them. The one you represent adheres to woke, LGBT and progressive ideas, while their real and immediate priority is the end of the month and a saturated job market.

For the rest of the youth, the observation is simple: you don't listen to them and they don't listen to you. The most blatant proof of this ideological manipulation are the EYE days at the European Parliament, the theater of the militant far left, which brings together feminist and Islamist FEMYSO workshops, spaces for discussion on racism and places for debate on transgender identity – the truth hurts to hear, I know.

European youth should know that this is how you represent their daily concerns. For you, youth is just a metaphor for the left. You systematically bring together in this hemicycle young people from the Grandes Ecoles, NGOs and federalist associations, making people believe that these people represent European youth. The plurality of opinions is non-existent whenever you give them the floor. This is demonstrated in particular by your online survey on European values. A real flop, moreover, which only received 5,000 responses out of the 88 million young people on our continent.

Youth is the easy argument to justify your federalist, leftist and anti-national campaign. It is to make the peoples of Europe believe that the new generations are ready to ratify the project of a United States of Europe prepared by old federalists disappointed by the electoral results.

But if there has been a constant since modern society has existed, it is that young people have always refused to be thought for them. Let's not put young people from our 27 very different nations in the same ideological basket. Young people are on the front line in the face of the crisis, in the face of the difficulty of doing business and in the face of international competition. The truth is that our young people struggle every day with the same difficulties as the rest of Europe. So, for the next European Year of Youth, get out of your progressive delirium, go and meet them in the different countries, rather than bringing in the sons of the bourgeoisie from the rich metropolises of our continent.
on behalf of the ECR Group . – Madam President! In October 2021, the European Commission presented a formal proposal to declare 2022 the European Year of Youth.

We criticized the late adoption of this initiative at the time. It was obvious that such a rush would make achieving the set goals too much of a challenge. Now it is confirmed. It was necessary to listen to rational arguments and foresee sufficient time to prepare real actions in such difficult times for young people.

It is young people in particular who have been affected by the economic, psychological and social consequences of the unprecedented measures introduced under the guise of fighting COVID-19, such as lockdowns or segregation of people instead of equality. School closures have caused damage to education. Young people have also lost the opportunity to train, volunteer or work. And even today, economic and political tensions caused, among others, by Russia's aggression against Ukraine do not make their lives easier.

This will not be changed by the resolution, which aims to establish the legacy of the European Year of Youth. A year in which, paradoxically, on average, nearly 14% of young people under 25 in the European Union were out of work.

There are also provisions in the resolution which are motivated by ideology and not real concern for the well-being of young people, and calls for actions that are incompatible with the principle of subsidiarity. These include calling on Member States to include citizenship education - in the form of global and EU citizenship - in their national curricula, although the area of education is an exclusive competence of states.

on behalf of The Left Group . – Madam President, the EU today is admittedly in a very difficult position. In just a decade it has experienced a worldwide economic crisis, a pandemic of a deadly virus and the consequences of an aggression, of a war. At the same time, the effects of the climate crisis are intensifying. The youth has fewer employment opportunities.

For the first time since the Second World War, the youth is experiencing a lower standard of living compared to their parents. It was in this context that we have decided to dedicate the year 2022 to youth and have set four main objectives: to renew the positive perspectives for young people and help them overcome the effects of pandemic on their lives; to support and empower young people to become active and engaged citizens; to better inform young generations about opportunities available to them from public policies at EU, national, regional and local levels; and to mainstream youth policy across all relevant Union policy fields.

However, in order to meet the EU’s expectations, it takes much more than designating a European Year. We have to increase public spending on education so that every child can have a high quality education, provide employment opportunities for everyone, increase wages and ban unpaid traineeships. Racism and other forms of discrimination are diseases that cut through our society to undermine our values. We should treat this immediately.

We have to focus on combating discrimination, address the challenges faced by young people who are discriminated. The creation of a fully-fledged EU youth test that will not merely become a bureaucratic checklist, but rather tackle these issues in a holistic way, can help achieve our aims.

Finally, we have to extend the year until 9 May and, more importantly, to defend and promote the legacy of the European Year of Youth. As the lyrics of a Greek song tells: ‘defend the child, because if a child is saved, there is hope’.
– (IT) Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, a few quick thoughts at the end of this European Year of Young People.

I have toured many schools, I have opened European workshops, meeting and discussion places where to build active and responsible participation, I have listened to many young people and I have felt in them the ever stronger need for knowledge of one's emotional self.

If politics really wants to have an impact on the growth of our young people, it is necessary to promote a school that knows how to adopt a formative assessment that pays attention to faces and emotions more than to products and cognitive processes.

We need to re-establish an authentic dialogue with young people and to do this we need to sit among them, because they are tired of being told "you have to be more competent, you have to be responsible, you have to be able to plan for yourself, you have to be resilient". I tried to sit among them and confront them, I understood many things, but one of all: they are young people who would like a school based on deep emotions and authentic relationships and not just on mere knowledge or sterile grades, which they have little to do with one's emotional self.
I promised them that this school is possible, with patience and courage we will continue to build it together.

– Madam President! Mr. Commissioner! The European Year of Youth 2022 is proof of the European Union's commitment to young and future generations. However, our activities for young people cannot end on 31 December. We need to build on the long-term legacy of this year because we need real participation by young people in politics. We owe them concrete results.

I deplore the situation in which the year started and, in particular, the hasty pace of adoption of the regulation, which subsequently delayed the implementation and financing of many projects. I hope that in the future the Commission will ensure that the European Years can be prepared in good time for all stakeholders.

During this year, during meetings with young people, we learned a lot from them. We know what is important to them, what their policy wishes are. We are committed to listening to the voices of young people, as we want to work together to shape the future of the European Union, taking into account their aspirations.

This European Year of Youth, which is coming to an end, should lead to a change in the way we involve young people in policy-making and decision-making. Whether on climate issues, social affairs or digital development, young people are at the heart of our policies and political priorities. They are, above all, the future of our common Europe.

– Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! A study published on Monday shows: More than two-thirds of young people are worried about the future and rate the general situation worse than ever before. War in Europe, inflation, climate change, the economic and energy crisis create a massive sense of insecurity; the European Year of Youth could not change that.

And just like a year ago, I'm standing here raising the same demands: finally abolish unpaid internships! Adequate remuneration for work done is a matter of respect and equal opportunities for young people. I don't want only young people from rich families to be able to afford an internship. And let's work together on structures that ensure a noticeable participation of young people in the long term!

However, rather than act, the Commission has preferred to use event mapping to demonstrate that it can also map. Over 8,000 activities have been mapped, many of which would have happened anyway. So this diligent work served more as self-affirmation. The year passed largely unnoticed by the young people, with nothing coming out of it for them.

That's why we're calling for the year to be extended to May 8, 2023, to finally deliver something in the extra time that could make the year a success after all. Finally come up with a proposal to ban unpaid internships and at least propose Council conclusions on involving children and young people in political decisions at all levels! Nobody is interested in a half-baked youth test that is more like a supervised discussion group than it represents real participation.
Let us work together on appropriate measures by May 9th and get them off the ground – otherwise the European Year of Youth will remain a farce.

– Madam President, dear Commissioner, indeed the European Year of Youth 2022 was a good decision. And this was a good decision because it allowed us to listen better to our young generation. In my political group, in Renew, we had the Renew Europe Task Force set to have meetings and several interactions with the young people. Our youth political organisations have been involved in, and we’ve exchanged about, the youth’s needs: about the need for paid internships, about the need for learning opportunities, about the need for digitalisation, a more inclusive society, about the mental health challenges, about the feeling of belonging, about the need for their access to decision-making process.

And I’m really glad that we have young people that are present with us today and will hear us. The fact that we are not going to take all these things easily; we will try to put together the implementation for that.

One important part is related to the investment in the young generation, the next generation. We have the Child Guarantee, we have the Youth Guarantee, and we need to push that further. But then if we care about the youth, we should have them on board today, not in a distant future. We should allow them to be part in designing their future today. If we want better policies for youth, we need to have you, the young people, involved in decisions, and having this youth impact test mainstream today. To say that we care about young people, it means that we need to get them on board with us for their good.

– Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner! It is always said: there is magic in every beginning. And I think it's actually the same with life. Because I would say, looking back myself, the first ten years felt so much longer than the last ten years that I've been on the planet right now. That's why I think the focus on young people is extremely important - that means that there was the European Year of Youth, that was a super good idea, even if nobody noticed anything about it, there was no money for it and no laws for young people on the have come away.

The European Year of Youth threatens to simply fizzle out like the bird of the year – that is the hoopoe. And that is exactly what we must prevent. The European Year of Youth simply has to be the starting signal for a very clear focus on young people, and I think the Commission is already on the right track and has really understood that it is about making happy people to create this continent, of course it is important that you create the happiness of the youth.

But, as I said, there is still a lot to do to achieve this. We need a ban on unpaid internships - this has been mentioned so many times. We finally have to do something for the mental health of our young people because it's a huge problem across the continent. Of course we have to extend the European Year of Youth so that people on this continent really get to know about it. And I would also like to ask you to create digital participation formats for young people in our democratic processes so that the hurdles are lowered.

PARA.EMPHAS: (The speaker agreed to answer a request to speak using the blue card procedure.)

INTERVENTION.PARA: Request to speak according to the “blue card” procedure . – Dear Mr. Gallée! There is one difference compared to the hoopoe: the hoopoe is protected in a special year.

That's why I would be interested: We currently have the situation that a lot of young people have mental problems, that a lot of young people are struggling with fears for the future - climate change, a war. Which Commission measures would you consider important in order to really support people?

What can the European Commission really do to support the mental health of young people and to ensure that in Europe nobody thinks about violence against themselves, thinks about suicide and we really get back to future positivity?

Response to a request to speak under the "blue card" procedure . – What is of course first and foremost the most important thing is that the livelihood for young people to continue to exist on this planet is created at all, which means that containing the climate crisis must of course have the absolute, highest priority, because that too, of course is the greatest threat to young people. If we think about the fact that we continue with our CO2 emissions as before, then in 100 years this planet will no longer be incredibly habitable. So, of course, that's above all.

Then there are many other projects that really create perspectives for young people and open up perspectives. These are offers to travel, these are offers to get to know the continent. These are of course, just as has already been mentioned, a ban on unpaid internships, so that we really offer young people who do not have the financial resources the same opportunities, so that they do not fall into the same patterns and are eaten up by a system that ultimately only abuses them as cheap labour.

– Madam President! At the beginning of the year, Ursula von der Leyen asked: What does the EU really mean for our youth? She would have asked better: What has the EU done for our youth? Because there are clear answers.

In Germany, more than a quarter of all children are at risk of poverty or social exclusion, more than the EU average. In Germany, almost 6% of 25-29 year olds are experiencing severe deprivation today, twice as many as in 2019. This puts Germany in the poorest quarter of the 27 EU member states. Only 73% of all Germans have completed secondary school – well below the OECD average of 80%. The German education budget in 2019 was the highest in the EU at almost 230 billion euros - or 6.6% of the gross national product.

But there is plenty of money only for German lessons for migrants and the indoctrination of young people. The language and mathematical skills of elementary school students and 15-year-olds are steadily declining in an international year-on-year comparison; this applies to Germans to Europeans and to all Europeans to Asians. European universities are also falling behind.

And despite massive public borrowing, youth unemployment in many regions of southern Europe is still between 35 and 50%. European women today have fewer than 1.5 live births, while women in West Africa have an average of five – of course you want to bring them all here.

Conclusion: The European Union is also failing when it comes to our young people. The fact that young people are now allowed to vote from the age of 16 and that more MPs are elected before they graduate does not change anything.

– Madam President, young people of Europe: Brussels proclaims a European Year of Youth, but tells you that you will not own anything. Others have decided what you have to do, think, feel, live or decide until 2030.

Never in history had youth been condemned to live a life more miserable than that of their parents. Make an effort, study, work and do not accept the crumbs of their cultural bonds. It is their world that is in ruins, not yours. It is their agenda that forces you to share the car, the house or the job, not yours.

You are young and you have every right to live in danger and recklessness — "do not eat meat", "do not drink wine", "do not have a stable job", "do not enjoy prosperity in the place where you were born" —. Forge strong bonds: your parents and grandparents. Culture and tradition. Your shared history, which is the nation. Set fire to all that is provisional. Audacity and courage to conquer the permanent.
They will accuse you of being young and they will tell you that things cannot be changed with enthusiasm.
But I assure you that if your illusion overflows, you will know how to drag all those who want to mortgage your future.
Safety in the streets, strong families, stable jobs and a homeland that protects you.
– Madam President, attention, ladies and gentlemen, drum roll: the European Year of Youth is coming to an end.

The European Year of Youth. I took the test last night, I went to Strasbourg and I asked all the young people I met if they had heard of the European Year of Youth. Well, can you imagine that not a single one answered me yes. Not one.

However, it could have been an event. It had every reason to be, this European Year of Youth. With the explosion in the number of young people forced to start their working life by queuing at the Restos du Coeur. One in five people queuing for food aid are between the ages of 15 and 25 – between 15 and 25! It made sense, this European Year of Youth, given the number of students who navigate between scholarships and odd jobs and who are forced to settle for one meal a day because they cannot pay their bills. Yet, we can say that today, this European Year of Youth has been a missed opportunity.
The Youth Guarantee. The Youth Guarantee could have given young people access to real, stable and quality employment. But no, finally, it installs them in precariousness.

On minimum income, we expected a real binding directive from the European Commission, a directive that gives everyone access to a minimum income, regardless of their age. This directive would have forced France to put an end to discrimination against young people under 25 in access to RSA. But no, we had a recommendation.
Even the interns. Trainees were forced last week to come before the European Parliament to ask us to ban this modern slavery of unpaid traineeships.

So, it's true, I admit, I had taken a liking to large-format posters with smiling young people saying 'European Year of Youth' in the morning when you arrive at the European Parliament. It's true that I will miss it. But admit, admit, we could have done so much better.

– Madam President, we’re concerned about the youth participation and engagement in our European project. Well, what hundreds of Catalan youth are facing right now for their engagement in politics, following their protest, are arrests, trials and prison sentences, police brutality and abuse, and unrelentless infiltration and spying in youth organisations, without – without – judicial oversight.
This is the reality of youth today in Spain, which is in the European Union. Meanwhile, Mr Sánchez’s government is about to pass new laws making repression against dissidents even easier.

Commissioner, colleagues, we say that we need to engage youth in Europe. We have it! Youth are committed to justice and freedom. What we need is that the Commission stops endorsing repression and starts protecting human rights!
– Madam President, good morning Commissioner, good morning to all those who are young in age but also in spirit.

– Madam President, with the European Year of Youth, we want to encourage young people who lost many opportunities during the COVID-19 pandemic. We know that young people do not like formalism and they know very well that we cannot solve all their problems in one year. But since we have this opportunity, let's use it. I really like working with young people. I need their input, feedback and also their energy. And I would like to take this moment to thank those who are very active within the framework Center for European Volunteering , European Youth Forum , Czech young people and young democrats, who supply me with their suggestions, and I know that they have also been involved in this year. It was, for example, a meeting EPP4Youth , attended by hundreds of young people, who were excited about the opportunity to meet their peers. We are preparing another event together with the European Commission and the Council. It will be the final conference with young people on December 6th, which I believe will bring further stimuli.

Of those that are very often emphasized by young people, I want to mention one that they consider very important, and that is the demand for much better information about the EU in school education. It may surprise someone, but it is logical. Young people see their future in the European Union and fear misinformation. It turns out that one of the ways could be joint projects of teacher academies implemented under Erasmus+ or Jean Monnet, and the European Parliament in its resolution asks the European Commission to take measures and enable the creation of a concrete educational framework for European citizenship. This would be a really tangible result of this year's youth year and would be useful for young people in the future.
– (IT) Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, a few weeks after its conclusion we have the opportunity to discuss the European Youth Year.
A year that missed its goals, first of all to really reach the young European generations, understand their needs, especially after the pandemic and in the midst of the current social crisis.

I would like to remind the Commission that there is still time to act, giving concrete answers. Firstly by implementing the "EU Youth Test" so that there is a significant involvement of the new generations in the political decision-making process. Young people must be able to have a say when deciding on policies that will impact their future.

It is time to fight youth precariousness and give them the opportunity to enter the world of work with quality opportunities, starting with a regulatory framework at European level that prohibits unpaid traineeships and apprenticeships, and on this aspect the Commission and Member States must certainly do their part, but Parliament must also be clear and united on this request. We are the first to say enough to the era of free work in order to gain experience.

Education creates equality, but if the first step after graduation is an unpaid internship, we are just keeping existing inequalities intact. The pandemic has already forced young people to put their lives on hold. The least we can do is guarantee them a start in the career path without being in debt. We owe it to them, for the Europe of the future.
Finally, it is essential for us to give continuity to this work by extending the European Youth Year until 9 May 2023.

– Madam President! The European Year of Youth is coming to an end or, if you prefer, the European Year of Youth is not over yet. This means that today it is somewhat difficult to determine his ultimate success, or to speak in sufficient detail or concretely about his legacy.

Instead, of course, we can talk about concrete proposals to improve the living conditions of young people. There are a lot of areas that need to be fixed, we all know that, and it is impossible to list them in a minute, but it can be said, unfortunately, that we did not manage to do it this year. We have managed to hold many events, of course that is true and I absolutely support that, but it is not enough. And we can't even replace everything backwards or forwards with such activities.

Unfortunately, young people do not have one umbrella law, directive or act that is aimed only at them, so we must make sure that we always put them in the forefront. I them. With young people and for young people. This is the least we owe them.

– Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, this week we celebrated the 70th birthday of the European Parliament, which, by the way, is also the average age of a conservative politician in this House. I am obviously joking, but I have to tell it to all of us. We have to be honest. If you listen to the Beatles, the Foo Fighters or Limp Bizkit, you’re not young anymore. If the people that go clubbing over the weekend are half your age, you’re not young anymore. So the reality and the funny thing about an ageing societies is that if you’re older, you outvote the young or, to say it a bit differently, the closer you are to death, the more you decide about the future. This obviously leads to absurd situations where you have a German chancellor, Olaf Scholz, campaigning as a full campaign promise to never touch pension schemes. That’s a great strategy if you want to get the old ones.

A year of youth won’t change these structural issues. And so we have to ask ourselves, what can we actually do? I think what would really help is to actually give voting rights to 16-year-olds and also to ensure that every 18-year-old across this continent has the right to stand as a candidate for elections. We should prioritise the issues that will have a longer-term effect, which means we should not concentrate too much on the short term. The longer-terms are the ones that will actually affect the people who are young now or that are still to be born. That does definitely include the climate.

And then I think as parties, as politicians, we need to make a step, an extra effort, to talk to young people more and to basically show them that it’s more fun to be here to fight against oil and gas than to throw processed food at paintings.
– Madam President, when we talk about youth policies, we cannot disconnect them from concrete and necessary responses to the problems that young people face today.

It is essential to put an end to exploitation and the scourge of precariousness. Let there be appreciation of wages. That quality public services be guaranteed to young people and that concerns about the discrimination that persists, and there are still many, not be ignored, and about the dangers to peace in a world that belongs to everyone.

It is necessary that young people have their rights of access to education, culture, sport, decent housing, leisure, health and sex education, equality, participation in the associative movement guaranteed.

The European Union and its Member States really need to put propaganda aside and implement policies that enable young people to fulfill their expectations, put their abilities at the service of development and the well-being of all, and that can turn your dreams into life.

– Madam President, the objective of our 2022 European Year of Youth was to shine a light on the importance of Europe’s youth in building a better future, and to put them at the centre of decision making. I believe the EU year was successful in some parts in achieving this, but the work cannot stop. It is essential that we, as EU decision makers, continue to welcome young people in every aspect of our work.

We must build a lasting legacy. Yearly youth conferences and events should take place across all four corners of our Union, fostering local debates and encouraging young people to give their much—valued input into developing EU policy. In addition, I ask the Commission to adopt an EU youth test to mainstream a youth perspective into the preparation of all our European policies.

In September, I was delighted to welcome four aspiring parliamentarians from my Midlands–North—West constituency to the Parliament as part of the EPP’s Youth Week. I saw first hand the commitment our young people have to our European peace project, our future and the invaluable perspectives they offered to us all. I want to thank Chloe, Lisa, Amy and Dean for joining us at EPP Youth Week. Let us ensure that we continue to listen to the voices of young people and make their future our ultimate mission.

PARA.EMPHAS: (The speaker agreed to respond to a blue-card speech under Rule 171(8))

INTERVENTION.PARA: blue-card speech . – Thank you very much, Maria. I know that you are very motivated. You are very hardworking for youth. You mentioned many activities where you participated and actions for youth. But many of our colleagues mentioned that it was late, it was less time for how to raise awareness about a European Year of Youth.
So really, do you share these concerns about awareness of the European Year of Youth? And how can we enhance this awareness of young people and include young people in this decision policy process?

blue-card reply . – Thank you very much for the question, colleague. I do agree with you. I think we rushed it. I think it was a fantastic year. But ultimately, look at the room right now. We should have 705 MEPs talking about how successful the European Year of Youth was in their constituency. We don’t.

We should have younger people as part of this conversation, and not just the younger people sitting up here in the podiums. I think that when we talk about the European youth and protection and this lasting legacy, we also need to deep dive into what worked. I mentioned youth conferences and events, organised local events worked. But, ultimately, who wasn’t in the room? It was all those with different abilities not in the room. It was issues like mental health, like climate change, like the future of digitalisation and their impact on that. Was that heard? It wasn’t.

But now we have time, and ultimately I hope that in this building of a lasting legacy, we do take it seriously, and that in our Culture and Education Committee, as we had agreed, we continue to have youth voices heard because, as I mentioned, it is our mission to protect our peace project for the future.

– Madam President, Commissioner, youth is the most decisive period of life, a moment of personal flowering that you only live once and, as such, you have to take advantage of it. Hence the importance of this European Year of Youth to raise awareness about it.

However, commissioner, how many young people have known about the initiative? Unfortunately, not enough. We have failed to reach the general population. The motives? This year's organization started late and has had little funding and little involvement.

But still, we must ensure that this year's legacy goes further, that it helps young people overcome the effects of the pandemic, that it empowers them to be active and engaged citizens, that it informs them of all the opportunities it offers the European Union. Training is a central axis in the development of our young people and, without a quality, inclusive and barrier-free education, it will be much more difficult for them to achieve their goals.

I end with a key moment for our young people, the difficult transition to the world of work. It is a democratic imperative that we guarantee fair remuneration for all internships. It is a shame not to have had the support of the right to defend this very basic right. Due to their opposition, we have not been able to include it in the resolution that we are going to vote on, but young people can continue to count on the Socialists to continue fighting for their rights.

– Madam President, dear colleagues, when I entered this Parliament three years ago, I was president of the European Liberals, and in that capacity I had the great honour to travel through 35 European countries. I’ve met many young people from all over Europe. I’ve demonstrated for abortion rights in Poland. I’ve protested against upload filters. I joined the fight against youth unemployment.

All those young people I met had very similar hopes and dreams, filled with expectations for the future. There was always one thing that I heard from them when I was a youth politician, but now also being a parliamentarian: ‘listen to us’. Also, in the Year of Youth, I’ve been to many events, and at every single one of them, I was asked to ensure that this year of the youth will be more than just a show, that it will have a lasting effect, that there will be better processes to include young people.

When I hear the disrespect from the colleagues on the right, from these populists, the disrespect for young people and their involvement, I can just say I am so proud that the Bundestag, the German Parliament, has just approved voting rights for people as of the age of 16.
Young people want to be heard, young people deserve to be heard and, dear Commissioner Breton, you should really listen to young people, especially after the Year of Youth.

PARA.EMPHAS: (The speaker agreed to respond to a blue-card speech under Rule 171(8))

INTERVENTION.PARA: occurrence signaled by raising a blue card . – I heard from you about this activity, about your high activity among young people in recent years. I would like to ask you if this activity included a visit to countries where unemployment is the highest at the moment: Spain, Italy? What have you done, what do you propose to change this very unfavorable situation in terms of unemployment among young people? What do you propose in your activity?

blue-card reply . – I think this is actually an excellent question. We have a different situation of youth unemployment throughout the whole of Europe. Young people have many shared dreams – the first apartment, the first love, and also trying to find a good education, trying to find a job.

The fact is the situation varies throughout the European Union. But also the fact is we have different circumstances. We have governments that make laws that make it harder for young people to get into employment, that favour older colleagues over newer colleagues. We have different education levels and systems in different countries. I come from a country where we have a different education system that also is very training—based.

So I think, especially on fighting youth unemployment, we need to come together to learn from best practice examples to really enable young people into the labour market. Because young people are not just cheap labour; young people are the future. Young people are the hope for better employment. They are the bright ideas of the future. They are the ones that will create jobs in the future. They are the ones that will create new companies in the future.

So it all really comes down to what we bring for education. This is really where I see the Member States in responsibility. On the European level, we can ensure, for example, by being against unpaid internships, by having best practice exchange and knowledge trainings and really bringing young people together, that we also help our Member States to put young people first.

– Honorable Madam President, Honorable Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues! There are 74 million young people aged 14 to 29 living in Europe. This is relatively large. It is worth making an effort for them, but on the other hand, in a situation where we are talking about an aging society in Europe, not enough. Too little.

But research shows that young people want to be more proactive in society, they want to be more involved. They point to unemployment, which still reigns in Europe and is strongly present in many parts of the European Union. And it is right that we help them as much as possible. And this initiative, which came from the President of the European Commission in September 2021, to have the European Year of Youth next year, is more than welcome, but recognized.

I believe that youth organizations and other participants had insufficient time for good preparations and of course there are problems in implementation. And also for the next year, when it was proposed just before now that it will be the year of skills, which is a perfect idea, very good, but it has the same bad point as the previous initiative. We are too poorly coordinated in European policies regarding giving such initiatives.

That's why I have two big wishes. The first is that this initiative be extended for half a year, so that they can carry out their projects that the young people have set themselves. And the second initiative, I urge the European Commission to better coordinate such initiatives in the future, to talk to us, who are the decision-makers in education policies. The European Commission is primarily an executor, and it would be more than necessary for us to come together, look, analyze things and only then adopt very important initiatives, such as this year's.

- Honorable Chairperson, Commissioner, what have the European institutions specifically done for young people and what are the tangible long-term results of this entire year? I don't have an answer to that question, and I haven't heard it from the Commission either.

The text in front of us is relatively good, but the fact remains that the results will not be what we hoped for. What disappointed me the most is the fact that even now, a large part of Europeans do not know that this year is the year of the youth, and this speaks volumes about the way of promotion and implementation of activities, which, unfortunately, remained on the attempts of some member states, organizations and individuals, even and some of us who implemented projects in our countries ourselves.

In the whole process, the most concrete solutions and outcomes are missing. I will repeat what I said here almost a year ago. We must not sell platitudes to young people like you are our future, we trust in you, the world rests on young people and the like. And that's exactly what we did. Although I personally did do something concrete for the youth during this year, I am ashamed and really feel like I betrayed them. I don't know how those who didn't do anything feel, but I feel ashamed on their behalf.
Colleagues, the symbolism is nice, but it is not what young people want, and I am afraid that we have really disappointed them.

– Madam President, 2022 is the Year of European Youth, the year of a generation that went through so many crises recently. I expected the Commission to be more ambitious, to reach those who are less interested in politics.

We, as Renew, organised Renew4Youth – an event that brought together 145 European students, young European students who had fruitful exchanges. They came from the EU but also beyond. This event changed their vision of Europe.

Next year will be the European Year of Skills, and I am proud to be the rapporteur on quality traineeships. Traineeships should be paid. They should occur in better working conditions and trainees should have a real learning experience.

So I say to you colleagues, this is not something we do for ourselves. This is something we do for young Europeans, for the next generation EU. So let’s cooperate on that report, because they deserve it.

– Madam President, Commissioner Breton, by declaring the European Year of Youth, the Commission and the entire European Union made a strong commitment towards young people. I believe this commitment, but also the responsibility of the Union.

I checked the European Year of Youth portal for my constituency. It lists nearly 2 000 events in Romania, but they are not dedicated initiatives and have little to do with the objectives set out by the Commission for the dedicated year. I learned from youth organisations that these activities would have taken place in any case and that they are part of Erasmus+, third—country or other public—entity funded projects.

Imagine that Romania had an allocation of EUR 183 000 for the whole European Year project. The Commission paid just some days ago the first EUR 80 000. Because of this late payment there has actually been no possibility to spend even EUR 1 for the European Year in Romania, when the closing European event is around the corner. This is bad implementation of an otherwise well—intended policy.

Additionally, I learned that for many youth organisations, this year was particularly difficult as the financing through the Erasmus+ programme encountered delays and less organisations received administrative funds.

Colleagues, the message of the youth for us is clear. For them, every year is the European Year of Youth. They should be continuously supported, promoted, asked for advice in youth matters and in European policies, and their organisations given opportunities to have long—term financial stability. We should not deceive them again.

– Madam President, Commissioner, just over a month ago the Portuguese socialists invited 200 young people to come to the European Parliament to express their concerns about the present and the future. From among thirty proposals, young people chose nine priorities that they were able to present to the President of this Parliament: a European strategy for mental health, free European public transport, access to affordable housing and vouchers free were some of these priorities.
But there is one that unequivocally emerged as having a strong impact on his life and which is the biggest obstacle to his emancipation: unpaid work.
Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, let us be clear: there is only one reason why the ban on unpaid internships is not in this resolution and that is the opposition that the entire right maintains.

Once again, I would like to make our position very clear and call for progress in this direction: it is time to put an end to unpaid internships once and for all. On behalf of these 200 young Portuguese and, I am sure, thousands more and all those in this Parliament's gallery, this would be the best way to end the European Youth Year and give a sign of great hope to young Europeans.

– Madam President, dear Commissioner, dear colleagues, the European Year of Youth has so far been a success by involving young people from all member states in activities that have shown them what the European Union means and especially European policies.
A very important thing, especially when we are faced with extremely aggressive and, we must admit, quite effective campaigns to discredit the European Union as a political and democratic project.

The actions we do at the European level or European funding must reach more young people, have clear objectives and have effective and efficient consequences in European policies. There is a need for European actions and policies to be oriented towards improving the living and educational conditions of all young people, regardless of their material situation or the interest they show in politics.

The fact that many of those who participated in the organized debates put education first shows that they are open and eager to develop, progress and is a clear signal that the European Union should be much more involved in the educational field.

Dear Chairperson, the European Year of Youth rightly focused on young people who, unfortunately, again disproportionately feel the burden of the crisis in which Europe and the world have found themselves. At the same time, the new generations continue to show that they are the driver of development and that they possess a special power, the power of innovation, the power of creativity, the power of excellence.
That is why they deserve above all a safe and peaceful, but also a sustainable and digital European future.

The war in Ukraine is another shock for the young generation. Instead of sitting in classrooms or training on sports fields, young Ukrainians were forced to take up arms, a fate that no one deserves. Together with the rest of Europe's youth, young Ukrainians deserve a secure future, and these are things that today, unfortunately, we may take for granted, a safe home, a secured education, a secure job and a family life.
For young Europeans, the war in Ukraine is, unfortunately, another lesson and a reminder that these are values that our generations will have to fight for and will have to fight for.

– Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, a year for young people was a necessity. The question now arises of the continuity of our action for our young people. This year has highlighted how our young people have resources and ideas. Teacher yesterday, I saw him every day. As an MP today, I would like to encourage their spirit of initiative and their creativity more.

Intensifying our responses to improve integration, education for all, the fight against precariousness or even responding to mental health problems are our priorities. We must everywhere train our young people better and continue to make Europe a place of knowledge. European Child and Youth Guarantees need to be more visible and accompanied by more aggressive communication. We must promote mobility for our young people, especially those in our outermost regions, so that they can explore the world, other territories, other cultures and other languages. Erasmus+ is the most relevant device.

Bringing citizenship to life so that in 2024 our young people will vote massively in the European elections and become involved in a lasting way in European democracy. This is my roadmap for the legacy of this Year of Youth so that every young person without distinction has the place they deserve in our society.
– Madam President, poverty, fear, insecurity, this is also a part of millions of young people in Europe.

We live in challenging times. The Covid-19 pandemic, but also the war, brought concern, fear or a feeling of isolation. In Europe, but also in Slovakia, in my country, the number of young people who have extremist views is increasing, they encounter open aggression, we even recently saw how a young person murdered in Slovakia out of hatred.

Young people today need our support and understanding all the more. We have to assure young people that their views and opinions are very important to us. Young Europeans must feel our support. We must not underestimate the future of young Europeans, because they will one day be the ones to decide what Europe will be.
– Madam President, I would like to bring here, to continue, what my colleague João Albuquerque has already raised here: the European Year of Youth.

The European years are years of commitment and it is commitment that we have to talk about. And the Portuguese young people asked for the four commitments that my Colleague João Albuquerque spoke about, but they also asked: investing in energy independence through renewable energies; promote the professional retraining of those who lose their jobs due to the digital transition; the cleaning of the oceans; the protection of biodiversity; ratification by the European Union of the Council of Europe Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women and a European strategy on mental health.

These are commitments, commitments that Portuguese young people make to the European Institutions, and we, as the European Parliament, have to take these commitments into account. Because the European Years will only be a success if, effectively, we commit ourselves to the ideas, to the projects, which are shared in the debate throughout the entire European Year.
– Madam President, the European Year of Youth represented a unique opportunity to bring the European Union closer to young people.

This year I had the honor of receiving 100 young people at the European Parliament, mostly from the Autonomous Region of Madeira, an ultraperipheral region, to ensure that these young people, who live farther away and face greater challenges, are part of the decision-making that we have taken here for the your day to day. Because this departure from the Continental Plate should not mean a departure from the European project and opportunities must be equal for everyone, whether they live in São Vicente or in the center of Brussels.

The event has already been mentioned here. 9 for youth , with many Europeans, including 200 young Portuguese who were brought here to the European Parliament, within the scope of this action by the Portuguese socialist delegation here in this Parliament.

May this European Year not be a show. Let us take action in response to their appeals. The youngest are the political decision-makers of the coming decades. And it will be they, the young people of today, who will ensure that this European project continues.

member of the commission . – Madam President, thank you all for this interesting debate, for the support and commitment to advancing the European youth agenda. Thank you also to the very many young people who take part in these debates and to the less young people who accompany them.

A word to tell you that, given that the activities of the Year have been implemented in a spirit, as you know, of co-creation - which means that it is collaboration, of course, that is between the EU institutions, stakeholders, national coordinators and young people – defining the legacy of the European Year of Youth therefore also involves a collective effort.

As announced, the Commission will assess the results and the potential of the initiatives, propose ideas for a future more holistic, more cross-sectoral, more inclusive approach to youth participation. In particular, as a follow-up to the Conference on the Future of Europe, the Commission wishes to involve young people in policy-making through their systemic participation in citizens' panels, as well as by granting particular attention to the impact of new policies on the younger generation.

The European Year of Youth mobilized public authorities at all levels – European, national, regional and local. Thanks to the grants awarded by the Commission, some countries, such as Germany, Ireland or Finland, have set up micro-finance grants awarded to groups of young people or actors in the youth.

Regarding the call to extend the Year. The work will obviously continue beyond 2022 and we will continue to set up initiatives for young people and integrate a youth component into existing initiatives. We will also keep the map of activities on the European Youth Portal open until at least the end of May 2023, so that stakeholders and national coordinators can still organize activities in the first half of the year. next.

Likewise, it can be said that the voice platform will in turn remain available, allowing young people to continue to express their vision. The Commission, I would like to say it here, welcomes the Year of Skills 2023 to enable more support for young people for better training and thus prepare them for the realities of the labor market.

In conclusion, ladies and gentlemen parliamentarians, the European institutions and the Member States have jointly committed themselves to the European Year of Youth 2022 and, we can say, have in a certain way created it together. As the Year comes to an end and we take stock of it, it will therefore be a question of drawing up, I repeat, all together a plan on how the legacy of this Year can and must be perpetuated. . The Commission looks forward to this prospect and to continuing our cooperation for the future of young people.
I have received a motion for a resolution1 pursuant to Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure.
The discussion is closed.
Voting will take place today, Thursday 24 November 2022.
1 See Minutes.

- The aim of the European Youth Year was to focus on young people, especially as a result of the Covid-19 epidemic, they must be offered more and better opportunities and ensure that they are heard, since young people are the future of Europe. I consider it important for young people to take an active role in public life, and to involve the young generation in social debates, in shaping youth policy and in making some policy decisions, and it is also important that the voice of young people reaches the EU institutions. Unfortunately, in the recent period, young people's trust in the institutions of the Union has been shaken, they have developed the impression that the central bodies of the EU are not interested in the citizens, they sweep grassroots initiatives off the table, an example of this is the case of the Minority Safepack. Instead of ideological battles, young people expect steps to help their future from the EU, especially in the fields of security, education and job creation. The role of communities and values is particularly valued these days. Youth organizations and their community-building and shaping role play a significant role in this. Furthermore, I consider it very important that investing in young people's learning opportunities has a direct impact not only on the future lives of young people as individuals, but also on the economic health and cohesion of society as a whole.

in writing . – 72% of young individuals considered that the most important success factor of the European Year of Youth would be if their demands would be better listened to by decision-makers. For this, we called for EYY outcomes to be mainstreamed across all related EU policies and we proposed to introduce a youth test by which we can measure the impact of all actions and policies on youth and the next generations. Access to quality and inclusive education, developing civic education modules, as well as youth entrepreneurship and environmental education are key points that we must act upon. At the same time, young people from vulnerable categories should be better supported in order for them to have a decent standard of living and more opportunities in regards to education, skills and labour. As S&D rapporteur on the EU budget, we obtained 8 million additional euro for the European Year of Youth in 2022, 123 million euro for Erasmus+ in the 2023 budget and requested financial allocations for the follow-up activities of the EYY. With almost 2000 youth activities organized in Romania, for example, I strongly believe we have to ensure continuity and coherence in our approach so that we can deliver on our commitments towards the young generation.

INTERVENTION.PARA: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, yesterday afternoon I hosted an event for civil society organizations. We received the boycott from deputies and assistants.
This does not respond to the plurality that deserves to be respected in this institution. We assume that steps will be taken to ensure democracy in this space.

– Madam President, I would just like to remind our dear friends on the far right why this event was organised. It was a peaceful action that aimed to remind one thing clearly and clearly: the right to abortion will remain the right that our institution will tirelessly defend. And that was the meaning of our presence.

I would just like to recall the words of Simone Veil, who said: 'You will have to remain vigilant throughout your life', 'all it will take is a political, economic or religious crisis for the right to abortion and women's rights to be in question". So know, colleagues, that you will always find us in your way when it comes to challenging women's rights.

– Madam President, simply, after hearing the words of the president of The Left Group, or her representative, we are absolutely free to carry out any act of political boycott of the events that take place in this Parliament.

INTERVENTION.PARA: President. – That is overwhelmingly adopted. This is significant.
Can I also say that this vote is significant not only for the much—needed funding it will make available for the people of Ukraine, but it matters for democracy.

Thank you for showing us, once again, that this Parliament is efficient, is effective, can act and can legislate urgently and fast. This is the democracy and legitimacy of European—level decision making.

INTERVENTION.PARA: – Madam President, I’m sorry but a brief indication for my colleagues in the EPP. There’s a wrong signal in three amendments. It concerns 36, 43 and 44: please vote minus. Sorry for this intervention. 36, 43, 44: vote minus, please.

– Madam President, on Monday, I had a point of order. I want to give a signal and ask the colleagues to stand up and to show a yellow card to FIFA because of their behaviour. If we stand and show our band, then we show that we are against what FIFA is doing in Qatar.
That concludes the vote.
