INTERVENTION.PARA: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the question for oral answer to the Commission on 'Revision of the Medical Devices Regulation - how to ensure the availability of medical devices?' by Angelika Niebler and Peter Liese, on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) ( O-000043/2022 – B9-0030/22 ) ( 2022/2960(RSP) ).

author . – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Doctors, hospitals and manufacturers of medical devices have been raising the alarm for over a year now: Important medical devices are going out, are no longer being manufactured and are being taken off the market. For example, balloon catheters for children's hearts are currently hardly available in Europe, and children with congenital heart defects can then no longer be operated on.

What happened? In 2017 we passed the new version of the Medical Devices Ordinance. The aim at the time was to achieve greater patient safety. The breast implant scandal in Germany and France triggered the revision of the Medical Devices Ordinance at the time. With the new version, we wanted stricter requirements for the certification of medical devices.

Today, however, we unfortunately have to realize that numerous medical products are simply not re-certified because the financial and bureaucratic effort is simply too high, especially for many medium-sized medical product manufacturers; this applies in particular to niche products. Therefore, I believe - in view of the current difficult supply situation with some vital medical products - something urgently needs to be done now. The Commission must finally present a proposal for an amendment to the Medical Devices Regulation. We have been asking the Commission to do this for months. Nothing has happened so far, at least from what I can tell, and actually I think it's a scandal.

I would therefore like to put three questions to the Commission today. Firstly, how does the Commission intend to ensure that medical devices remain available, particularly in hospitals, so that patients who urgently need them can survive?

Second, I propose that certificates already issued remain valid at least until the review of a recertification application is complete. Question to the Commission: Is that a consideration that is shared?
And thirdly, is the Commission considering amending the Medical Devices Regulation so that at least niche products that were already certified under the old regime no longer need recertification?
I am very curious how the Commission will reply to these three questions.

Member of the Commission . – Mr President, honourable Members, first of all I would like to thank honourable Members Niebler and Liese for putting this very important topic on the agenda today. I believe we all agree that patient access to safe medical devices in Europe is essential. And I believe that we also all agree that both access and safety are fundamental priorities in everything we do in this area.

When the European Parliament and the Council adopted the Medical Device Regulation in April 2017, the objective of this was to strengthen quality control and market surveillance. And as MEP Niebler mentioned, we must not forget the breast implant scandal of 2011 that triggered the revision of this legislation. The reasons we had to act as the EU back then for patient safety remain every bit as valid now.

In May 2024, the transitional period of the Medical Device Regulation will be coming to an end. We have made a lot of progress to implement new rules. Some 34 notified bodies have been designated under the regulation. Their capacity has significantly increased compared with the situation under previous EU directives. We have set up expert panels and their secretariat in the European Medicines Agency. They are essential for the more thorough assessment of clinical data.

Yet as we move towards the end of the transition period, it has become extremely clear that ensuring patient access to these devices is not guaranteed. And we are, in fact, facing a serious risk of shortages of medical devices.

Honourable Members, being aware of this risk, we have tasked our experts to take actions and to develop options forward. Aside from continuously monitoring the situation, we are together working with the Medical Device Coordination Group on finding solutions to this problem. A list of mitigation actions was adopted in August in order to increase notified body capacity and to boost preparedness among manufacturers. And several actions are already under way in order to be able to solve the problems that we have seen.

But beyond these efforts, there are calls for additional actions from Members of this House and from several Member States and, of course, from stakeholders. And they include calls for an amendment to the regulation to extend the transition period. We are looking into legislative measures such as amending the regulation to avert the risk of shortages of critical medical devices, and we are already consulting all relevant stakeholders as part of this assessment.

The issues raised in the oral question include the specific situation of so—called orphan devices for small patient groups, which are part of that ongoing assessment. In the meantime, I am pleased to announce and share with Parliament today that the Medical Device Coordination Group has already set up a task force on orphan devices, and has held a workshop with clinicians and industry and other stakeholders.

So what are the concrete next steps for this file? In December, at the occasion of the Health Council, I will be providing the clear proposed solutions to all EU health ministers. My objective is to address both the very short-term issues, but also the structural issues that have appeared. My other objective is the intention to keep this Parliament fully involved in this process. Your support in averting shortages of medical devices is crucial, and I look forward to hearing your views today.
on behalf of the PPE Group . – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Medical care in Europe is in great danger. This is especially true when it comes to caring for children.

I used to work in a children's clinic, and my medical colleagues in children's surgery and children's cardiology say: "We are on the verge of making medicine from the 1950s because modern equipment is no longer available."

There are many reasons: Brexit, Corona, but also, in my view, majorities in the European Parliament and in the Council that have exaggerated the good cause, that have overshot the mark in the good cause of patient protection. Back then, we warned against too much bureaucracy. But so be it; lamenting is useless. The causes don't really matter either; we need a solution now.

I fully support what Mrs Niebler suggested. Dear Commissioner, dear Stella, we need these steps quickly and we need them boldly. My group is ready to agree to such proposals very, very quickly. And it is important that we find viable solutions in the long term, especially with the children. One Orphan Device Regulation – a special regulation that provides incentives for medical devices in children, for example – exists in the USA; we need them in Europe too. The protection of the most vulnerable little patients must be worth more to us than it has been up to now.

on behalf of the S&D Group . – Mr. President, a clinician, with a respirator that gives 12 breaths per minute and a breathing volume of 0.7, what he wants is to put in 8.4 liters in one minute. This means that it is accurate. And that is what the Regulation of sanitary products that came into force in 2017 intended, that is, that sanitary products did not fail. None. And we know that there were cases in which it was like that – the commissioner mentioned it. There were, for example, failed breast implants, hip replacements... That happened.

Therefore, this Regulation has been a good regulatory framework to improve the reliability of medical devices. We also believe that it is more transparent and fair. In addition, health and medical professionals have also recognized this. Because all we want is reliability.

During the pandemic we also worked on the reinforcement Regulation of the European Medicines Agency, in which we also included elements that favor the availability of health devices, especially in crisis situations. But we must also consider that we have several legislative tools.

Of course, of course, we must assess whether, as a result of the entry into force of this Regulation, there are some cases of medical devices for which there is a risk of shortage, especially in rare diseases or in pediatric diseases (in pediatric treatments). And it may be necessary to make certain derogations, as has been done previously.

It will have to be studied on a case-by-case basis. But I don't think we should make this legislation softer and have less confidence in what we use to measure or to treat patients, to measure their physical variables and the treatments that we apply.

Peter Liese mentioned it before: it could be other factors (the supply chain has been interrupted, part of the production was not based in Europe...). Perhaps we have to act on those factors, locate them, solve them and act on it. Not so much about the legislation.

Therefore, it seems good to me that the Commissioner, among other things, has proposed to study with the Member States what is happening. But I believe that we should avoid claims such as that this regulation is causing patients in the European Union to receive worse healthcare. I do not believe that this Regulation is the cause. Adjustments will have to be made, improvement procedures will have to be established and solutions will have to be sought. But what we need above all is high reliability and reliability in healthcare devices.

on behalf of Renew Group . – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, let us never forget that the proposal to revise the legislation on medical devices was published following the drama of the PIP breast prostheses in 2012. Ten years later, we are still to discuss the implementation of this legislation. This does not correspond to our vision of an ambitious, pragmatic and above all independent Europe of health.

Patient safety cannot be an adjustment variable. Health standards are as, if not more, imperative than other European legislation. We have to admit that the implementation of the regulation is today in danger, due to the too low number of notified bodies, certainly, but also due to the lack of anticipation of certain manufacturers and the lack of specialized personnel.

It's true, for several months, all players have been sounding the alarm and it's time to respond with pragmatic solutions that are acceptable to everyone. So, agree to adapt the regulations once again, but temporarily and marginally, to avoid potentially dangerous supply disruptions, but not to call into question this ambitious regulation absolutely necessary for the safety of European patients.
on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group . – Mr President, dear all, we have already extended the deadlines for the new rules of the Medical Devices Regulation to apply until May 2024.

The European Parliament was clear that we do not wish another postponement that would be in the disinterest of patients. Now, if the regulation poses issues that will affect access to care for patients, perhaps it really requires other changes to the regulation. So that would be my question to the Commission. What does the Commission recommend?

I would like to stress that Parliament should be involved early on regarding the discussion. I was happy to hear from the Commissioner, who said it is important that the European Parliament is involved in order to discuss possible changes to this regulation instead of having again to face another urgent procedure to extend the deadline to apply the regulation’s rules, which are important.

on behalf of group ID . – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, while President Macron at the APEC forum asks us which side we are on – China or the USA – and says that we need a single world order, or while the G20 is announcing the strengthening of global health governance with the leadership role of the WHO, Europe is dying under the Brussels bureaucracy. France, it records deaths in its emergencies for lack of care.

Today, you must not get sick because there are no more hospital beds. Do you have cancer? You will have to wait for places to become available or for you to have a well-placed friend in a hospital. Private jet forums will never have these problems. In France, we would have twice as many scanners per inhabitant as Greece or Denmark. Our French hospitals lack nurses and scanners. We are seeing the same shortcomings with this 2017 regulation which established a new framework for in vitro diagnostic medical devices, such as HIV and Covid screening tests or pregnancy tests. We are talking here about medical devices that hospitals in the European Union can keep, but you should know that Macron's France closed 4,400 hospital beds and suspended 15,000 nursing staff during the Covid crisis. Instead of improving, patient care has deteriorated in Europe and France. In Poissy, this summer, a woman died after 28 hours spent in the emergency room, on a stretcher.

So we have hospitals that are no longer able to supply themselves with medical devices, European companies drowned in bureaucracy and that have to stop producing products that have always been used. In all areas, the Commission is setting up a system of private companies responsible for certifying products. A market of 140 billion euros in 2022.

But let's come back to our subject with concrete examples. How can it be explained that the German private certifier TÜV Rheinland can still practice when it was involved in the case of the PIP breast prostheses? TÜV certified these prostheses before they were marketed, then carried out thirteen checks in thirteen years without ever noticing anything. Certify everything, but verify nothing. 400,000 victims including 30,000 in France. Ten years of waiting and legal battle. For Covid vaccines, we are not talking about 1,000 deaths in 30 years, but 11,000 in one year, in Europe, according to the latest figures from the EMA.

Other pharmaceutical scandals: Pfizer was fined $2.3 billion in 2009 for submitting false claims to authorities for the anti-inflammatory drug Bextra; Johnson & Johnson, $775 million in 2019 for downplaying the risk of life-threatening complications from its blood thinner Xarelto.
Private jet forums forget this sad reality. The Bali G20 statement posted on the White House website obviously has the answers to your questions.

on behalf of the ECR Group . – Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, looking at the facts surrounding the revision of the Medical Devices Regulation, I am once again disappointed to be convinced that something is deeply wrong in the way decisions are made and implemented in the functioning of this European Union. There is no explanation why, after this regulation was adopted, due to the excessive bureaucratic and financial effort required to re-certify a set of medical devices, even those of excellent quality and used for a long time, can suddenly disappear from the market, because companies decide to withdraw them without any explanation.

The result is visible – a reduction in the availability of medical devices across Europe, which worsens patient care. Until recently, everyone in this room had become a medical professional, understood pandemics, discussed the Chinese virus, what was, what was not, how medical care was being depleted, lack of medicine, lack of ventilators and so on and so forth. However, it seems that this has passed as an explanation, everyone has forgotten it, and now the same mistakes are being repeated again. This behavior is inexplicable, and it is inexplicable to deprive the citizens of the member states of the European Union of adequate, timely and necessary medical care.

Madam Commissioner, it is time for the European Commission to start acting adequately, to mind its own business. This is in your interest, not ours. We often criticize you for these things, but it is not a bad thing to take to end this vicious practice of legislation that affects the interests of the citizens of the Member States.

– (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, our hospitals and carers are under very heavy pressure and, today, there is a new difficulty on top of that concerning the supply of medical equipment. Respirators, defibrillators, prostheses and many other devices, essential to everyone's health, are at risk of running out, with all that this implies in terms of patient care.

Companies in the sector and our Parliament have already alerted the European Commission on several occasions in recent years. In addition to the current economic situation, these companies see themselves imposing heavy administrative constraints and sometimes, today in any case, impossible to fulfill for lack of certification bodies in sufficient numbers. These companies today need security. So we are turning to the European Commission, which we are asking to quickly find concrete solutions.

– Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Our goal from everyone involved in the legislative process is to ensure the legal framework for a safer and easier life for European citizens. I am convinced that this was also the purpose of the revision of the Medical Devices Ordinance. However, patients and providers of niche products are facing greater demands than before, facing difficulties that they need to devote special resources to solve, implying high costs for patients or healthcare systems in the Member States.

I understand the goal of better protecting patients, but we need to monitor the real impact of implementing the regulations and make changes quickly so that patients have the same access as before to the medical devices they need, without paying more. We need to keep a close eye on the market to spot any problems that arise and very quickly find the fixes that patients need.

– Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner! We want a transformation towards sustainability and we want safe medical devices. But I get a lot of calls for help from companies in my constituency: Specialized products, such as scalpels for children, with limited editions and often made by small companies, are lumped together with mass-produced products from multinational companies. The manufacturers then withdraw the products from the market because they cannot meet the requirements, and we cannot want that.

We are running into an immense bottleneck. Up to 24,000 certificates will expire by May 2024, but only 6,300 certificates can be issued annually by the notified bodies. We must prevent bottlenecks and life-saving products from being withdrawn from the market.

One thing is clear: the current situation is not satisfactory. We need quick health solutions now, but in the medium term the regulation must be put on a resilient footing so that this drama does not repeat itself every few years.

– Mr President, colleagues, I absolutely want to see the full and effective application of the Medical Device Regulation, because it is extremely important for patients and for those providing their medical care to give assurance on the safety and the effectiveness of these devices.

But I do not want to see a situation develop whereby there will be a shortage – or, as some fear, an unavailability – of vital products. Doctors say that they are already struggling with shortages and they are fearful that this situation will become much more serious.

The slow implementation of the medical device legislation and the limited capacity of notified bodies has led to this situation. Without urgent action, this situation will only get worse and these shortages will impact on patients and on the healthcare system.

So, Commissioner, I welcome your statement today that in December you’re going to bring forward clear proposals to address this situation. I would hope that this will include proposals for a targeted legislative solution that will protect those devices that are already on the market. What we need, as well, is a targeted or tailored transition period for some devices.

– A Uachtaráin, Ireland has urgent and significant concerns regarding the Medical Devices and In Vitro Diagnostics Regulations. There are real issues with the implementation of the directive that need to be addressed.

The regulations introduce new certification requirements. However, substantial and immediate certification bottlenecks mean that Ireland could face considerable shortages in key medical products in the near future. This places patients’ lives at risk and our healthcare system under strain.

If these bottlenecks are not addressed by the May 2024 deadline for certification, there is a risk that one in four med—tech products currently in use could be discontinued. At a time when Europe should be building up homegrown industry and investing in innovation, without some adjustments to the implementation of this regulation we risk losing med—tech firms to the US and other markets outside the EU, and thus losing out on investment and competitiveness in this area.
The Irish Government is calling for a legislative proposal to prevent the loss of existing safe and essential med—tech products.

- Honorable President, Honorable Commissioner, in fact, if we want to provide good help to our patients, we must have three things: specialists, tools and patient trust. Today we are talking about tools that we can use to treat patients. I would like to call on the Commission not to reduce the quality requirements, but to reduce the bureaucracy that today weighs down our medical device manufacturers and sometimes prevents us from ensuring the required quality and quantity of devices. I would call for all of us to make a joint effort to reduce red tape and implement an increase in production in the European Union to ensure the necessary amount of medical devices for patients and doctors, but at the same time to really reduce the red tape that is oppressive, and in this way, without delaying the further implementation of our decisions, already in 2024 have a changed situation.
– Mr President, Commissioner! On Twitter today, the European Medical Association points out that it urges:
‘European doctors aim to ensure the availability of medical devices.’

This is a warning signal that we cannot take note of with the otherwise usual technical calm here. If small children can no longer be treated because the necessary items are no longer available because there are bottlenecks in the approval process, then we cannot be indifferent. First of all, this is a catastrophe for the patients affected, but of course it is also an economic problem, because the approval process in the USA is now faster than it is here.

And so, Commissioner Kyriakides, here it is political leadership required. It is not enough to say that something is being done there and here. You must take political responsibility for making progress at this point. Because if we don't act now, in two years we will lose over 20,000 certified products. And we can't afford to do that in the interest of the patients, but we can't afford it either because our economy depends on it.
Therefore: Please take personal action now.

Member of the Commission . – Mr President, honourable Members, first of all, thank you for bringing this important file for discussion in the European Parliament. And I have said already that this is a priority for us, for the European Commission. And our intention is not, as has been heard, to hurt the citizens, but to protect them. So quality is paramount. And I can assure you that it is a political priority for the Commission and for myself, because we are fully aware of the challenges, and we have wasted no time.

Now, the data received from the notified bodies and industry show that the situation is indeed extremely challenging. Only around 2 000 certificates have been issued under the Medical Device Regulation, while about 23 000 will be expiring in May 2024. This is why the Medical Device Coordination Group has been working on a list of actions, and all stakeholders are involved, including the medical associations, in order to look at what we can change. And we expect that the important actions that we will take will make a real difference.
We are also, as a Commission, listening carefully to all calls for additional measures, including an amendment of the Medical Device Regulation. And we are proceeding with the next steps.

Now, I don’t think there is anyone in this plenary who will say that the unavailability of medical devices needed for health systems and patients isn’t extremely worrying. And this is a priority. But the Medical Device Regulation allows Member States to grant at national level derogations from the applicable conformity assessment procedures. And in some Member States they are able to apply these to bridge the gap between the expiry of an old certificate and the issue of a certificate under the MDR.

The Medical Device Coordination Group is now working to find a uniform approach for these measures. However, we fully recognise that as more certificates expire, the worse the situation is expected to become. So we’re very conscious of the urgency that I have heard spoken in this plenary in order to avoid shortages of medical devices, which will put patient safety at risk.

The regulations on medical devices are a very important step towards providing safe and better performing devices, and these are to benefit the patients and health. As I’ve said, we’re working on a legislative proposal plus other actions. Our task is to ensure that safe devices – and this needs to remain a priority – remain available for patients and for our health systems.
So let me assure you that I will be remaining in very close contact with this House over the next few weeks and will keep you fully informed of our next steps.
The debate is thus closed.

INTERVENTION.PARA: – Mr President, I voted in favor of this report. The recent escalation of Russia's brutal military aggression, pardon the pun, against Ukraine is confirmation of its determination to violate Ukraine's fundamental rights to independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity within its internationally recognized borders and to destroy its viability as a state.

The bravery, courage and determination of the Ukrainian people to defend their country deserve deep respect and gratitude. Through the "Team Europe" approach, the European Union, its member states and the European financial institutions mobilized 19 billion euros at the beginning of the Russian military aggression for the economic, social and financial resilience of Ukraine. This, combined with support from the Union budget - €12.4 billion, including macro-financial assistance in support of the European Investment Bank, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, fully and partially guaranteed by the European Union budget, as well as additional financial support from Member States in the amount of EUR 7.3 billion. It should be part of our duty to support the attacked country so that it can resist the aggression.

Clár Beartais 2030 'Conair i dtreo na Deacáide Digití' a bhunú (A9-0159/2022 - Martina Dlabajová)

INTERVENTION.PARA: – A Uachtaráin, the Digital Decade Policy Programme is a key step towards the EU achieving its objectives for the digital transformation of society and the economy. The path to a Digital Decade Programme reinforces the EU’s position as a digital leader and promotes human—centred, inclusive and sustainable digital policies.

The past number of decades has seen significant developments in the internet, the digital economy and electronics, and the Digital Decade Policy Programme will ensure the EU achieves its aims for an inclusive and sustainable digital transformation.

This programme ensures that at least 20 million ICT specialists are employed in the EU by promoting the access of women to this field. The programme will also ensure more than 90% of SMEs in the EU will reach at least a basic level of digital integration.
I am therefore pleased to support the path to a digital decade.

Kehitysrahoituksen tuleva eurooppalainen rahoitusrakenne (A9-0270/2022 - Charles Goerens)
Den framtida europeiska finansiella arkitekturen för utveckling (A9-0270/2022 - Charles Goerens)
Buduća europska financijska struktura za razvoj (A9-0270/2022 - Charles Goerens)
An tOllstruchtúr Airgeadais Eorpach don Fhorbairt a bheidh ann amach anseo (A9-0270/2022 - Charles Goerens)

INTERVENTION.PARA: - Mr President, I am happy to support this proposal for the development of a European Financial Macrostructure. It will play a vital role in ensuring that the European Union fights against poverty and inequality. It will ensure that we work towards the post-establishment development goals of the United Nations and stop global climate change. This plan will ensure that the countries of the European Union and the institutions will work together to achieve policy integration. In addition, it will ensure that public money is used effectively. This plan will refer to the development of European Union policy after the pandemic and after the consequences of the war in Ukraine. The development of a European Financial Macrostructure will improve the visibility of the Union and the impact of the Union on the financial world.

INTERVENTION.PARA: – A Uachtaráin, the Energy Charter Treaty plays a key role in energy policy across Europe. However, in the absence of any substantial update of the ECT since the 1990s, it is clear that the modernisation of the Treaty is due. I welcome efforts by the EU and its Member States to drive the modernisation process of the Energy Charter Treaty, particularly on investment protection standards and the fostering of sustainable development.

I also welcome the position to end protections granted to investments in economic activities considered to be significantly harmful and that undermine the EU’s climate objectives. It is clear the Energy Charter Treaty is in need of reform, particularly given the current energy crisis and the fight against climate change.
I therefore call on the European Commission and EU Member States party to the ECT to support its modernisation and to ratify the modernised treaty.

INTERVENTION.PARA: – Mr President, I voted against this report emphatically because the measures under the Cohesion Regulation must be implemented by the Commission, which violate the principles of the rule of law and directly affect or seriously threaten to affect the good financial management of the Union. In no way does this policy, which is being pursued by the European Union and the European Parliament with regard to Hungary, to suspend 65% of the appropriations for commitments under the cohesion policy, correspond to the reality and to any logic of the European Union, of the idea of rule of law.

The "rule of law" theme is used to enforce policies in a number of member states, including Hungary. This is absolutely unacceptable and inadmissible, contradicts the nature of the Treaties and contradicts the idea of a European Union. For this reason, such an approach of extortion, of wringing one's hands cannot be supported in any way, because it is in these approaches that the increasing role of skepticism of many citizens of member states of the European Union is hidden.

INTERVENTION.PARA: – Mr President, I voted in favor of this report because the growing wolf populations in the European Union and the problem that these populations allegedly pose to biodiversity and traditional animal husbandry in Europe, as well as the need for a joint assessment of the conservation status and transboundary measures to protect and manage the population of large carnivores in a scientifically based way, correspond to the ecological requirements for wolf species that inhabit large areas and carry out large migrations. For this reason, hunting should be allowed, within the framework of good practice, the rules and the way these hunting parties work, so that they can carry out the useful activity of protecting the economy and protecting human lives and people's economy .

Bulgaria provides a positive example of how, in a country with the least investment in Europe in terms of wolf hunting, the range and number of this predator is increasing, despite the measures. On the other hand, the bear, as a strictly protected species in our country, has decreased by more than 30% in the last 10 years according to official data.

INTERVENTION.PARA: - Mr. President, I supported this resolution, this European Youth Year is already coming to an end.

It was also discussed in this plenary about the future of young people in Europe, during the Conference on the future of Europe, but I think we are doing too little for the transition from school to the workplace and we need much stronger tools to be able to support the young people who today are deeply affected by all transformations.

We have gone from a public health crisis to a new crisis that is depriving young people of many opportunities and I believe that the Commission has an obligation to ensure that Member States implement the Child Guarantee and the Youth Guarantee, mechanisms through which we can offer new practical solutions, so so that young people feel much better integrated and protected in European society.
This closes the agenda item.
